column2: '17Oct'
column3: 1)	" I'm glad you clarified that.

column1: Mr. Hankins
column2: I don't feel good about it
column3: and I think we ought to have a patient's bill of rights to take the medical decisions away from the HMOs and give them back to the doctors and nurses. I want to come back and tell you why
column4: but if you will forgive me
column5: I would like to say something right now at the beginning of this debate following on the moment of silence for Mel Carnahan and Randy Carnahan and Chris Sifford. Tipper and I were good friends with Mel and Randy
column6: and I know that all of us here want to extend our sympathy and condolences to Jean and the family and to the Sifford family. And I would just like to say that this debate in a way is a living tribute to Mel Carnahan because he loved the vigorous discussion of ideas in our democracy. He was a fantastic governor of Missouri. This state became one of the top five in the nation for health care coverage for children under his leadership. One of the best in advancing all kinds of benefits for children to grow up healthy and strong. And of course
column7: this debate also takes place at a time when the tragedy of the USS Cole is on our minds and hearts and insofar as the memorial service is tomorrow
column8: I would like to also extend sympathy to the families of those who have died and those who are still missing
column9: and the injured. Now
column10: Mr. Hankins
column11: I think that the situation that you describe has gotten completely out of hand. Doctors are giving prescriptions
column12: they're recommending treatments
column13: and then their recommendations are being overruled by HMOs and insurance companies. That is unacceptable. I support a strong national patient's bill of rights. It is actually a disagreement between us
column14: a national law that is pending on this
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill
column16: a bipartisan bill
column17: is one that I support and that the governor does not.

column1: I
column2: too
column3: want to extend my prayers and blessings
column4: God's blessings on the families whose lives were overturned yes -- tod -- last night. It's a tragic moment. Actually
column5: Mr. Vice President
column6: it's not true. I do support a national patient's bill of rights. As a matter of fact
column7: I brought Republicans and Democrats together to do just that in the State of Texas to get a patient's bill of rights through. It requires a different kind of leadership style to do it
column8: though. You see
column9: in order to get something done on behalf of the people
column10: you have to put partisanship aside
column11: and that's what we did in my state. We have one of the most advanced patient's bill of rights. It says
column12: for example
column13: that a woman doesn't have to go through a gate keeper to go to her gynecologist. It says that you can't gag a doctor
column14: doctor can advise you. The HMO
column15: the insurance company
column16: can't gag that doctor from giving you full advice. And this particular bill
column17: it allows patients to choose a doctor
column18: their own doctor if they want to. But we did something else that was interesting. We're one of the first states that said you can sue an HMO for denying you proper coverage. Now there's what's called an Independent Review Organization that you have to go through first. It says if youâ€™ve got a complaint with your insurance company
column19: you can take your complaint to an objective body. If the objective body rules on your behalf
column20: the insurance company must follow those rules. However
column21: if the insurance company doesn't follow the findings of the IRO
column22: then that becomes a cause of action in a court of law. It's time for our nation to come together and do what's right for the people
column23: and I think this is right for the people. You know
column24: I support a national patient's bill of rights
column26: and I want all people covered. I don't want the law to supersede good law like we've got in Texas. I think --

column1: Jim
column2: we have a direct disagreement on this.

column1: Absolutely not. I referred to the Dingle-Norwood bill. It is the bipartisan bill that is now pending in the Congress. The HMOs and the insurance companies support the other bill that's pending
column2: the one that the Republican majority has put forward. They like it because it doesn't accomplish what I think really needs to be accomplished to give the decisions back to the doctors and nurses and give you a right of appeal to somebody other than the HMO or insurance company
column3: let you go to the nearest emergency room without having to call an HMO before you call 911
column4: to let you see a specialist if you need to
column5: and it has strong bipartisan support. It is being blocked by the Republican leadership in the Congress.

column1: And I specifically would like to know whether Governor Bush will support the Dingle-Norwood bill
column2: which is the main one pending.

column1: Well
column2: the difference is is that I can get it done. That I can get something positive done on behalf of the people. That's what the question in this campaign is about. It's not only what's your philosophy and what's your position on issues
column3: but can you get things done? And I believe I can.

column1: What about the Dingle-Norwood bill?
I'm not quite through. Let me finish. I talked about the principles and the issues that I think are important in a patient's bill of rights. It's kind of Washington
column2: D.C. focus. Well
column3: it's in this committee or it's got this sponsor. If I'm the president
column4: we're going to have emergency room care
column5: we're going have gag orders
column6: we're going to have direct access to OB/GYN. People will be able to take their HMO insurance company to court. That's what I've done in Texas and that's the kind of leadership style I'll bring to Washington.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 1)	" I'm glad you clarified that.

column1: Mr. Hankins
column2: I don't feel good about it
column3: and I think we ought to have a patient's bill of rights to take the medical decisions away from the HMOs and give them back to the doctors and nurses. I want to come back and tell you why
column4: but if you will forgive me
column5: I would like to say something right now at the beginning of this debate following on the moment of silence for Mel Carnahan and Randy Carnahan and Chris Sifford. Tipper and I were good friends with Mel and Randy
column6: and I know that all of us here want to extend our sympathy and condolences to Jean and the family and to the Sifford family. And I would just like to say that this debate in a way is a living tribute to Mel Carnahan because he loved the vigorous discussion of ideas in our democracy. He was a fantastic governor of Missouri. This state became one of the top five in the nation for health care coverage for children under his leadership. One of the best in advancing all kinds of benefits for children to grow up healthy and strong. And of course
column7: this debate also takes place at a time when the tragedy of the USS Cole is on our minds and hearts and insofar as the memorial service is tomorrow
column8: I would like to also extend sympathy to the families of those who have died and those who are still missing
column9: and the injured. Now
column10: Mr. Hankins
column11: I think that the situation that you describe has gotten completely out of hand. Doctors are giving prescriptions
column12: they're recommending treatments
column13: and then their recommendations are being overruled by HMOs and insurance companies. That is unacceptable. I support a strong national patient's bill of rights. It is actually a disagreement between us
column14: a national law that is pending on this
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill
column16: a bipartisan bill
column17: is one that I support and that the governor does not.

column1: I
column2: too
column3: want to extend my prayers and blessings
column4: God's blessings on the families whose lives were overturned yes -- tod -- last night. It's a tragic moment. Actually
column5: Mr. Vice President
column6: it's not true. I do support a national patient's bill of rights. As a matter of fact
column7: I brought Republicans and Democrats together to do just that in the State of Texas to get a patient's bill of rights through. It requires a different kind of leadership style to do it
column8: though. You see
column9: in order to get something done on behalf of the people
column10: you have to put partisanship aside
column11: and that's what we did in my state. We have one of the most advanced patient's bill of rights. It says
column12: for example
column13: that a woman doesn't have to go through a gate keeper to go to her gynecologist. It says that you can't gag a doctor
column14: doctor can advise you. The HMO
column15: the insurance company
column16: can't gag that doctor from giving you full advice. And this particular bill
column17: it allows patients to choose a doctor
column18: their own doctor if they want to. But we did something else that was interesting. We're one of the first states that said you can sue an HMO for denying you proper coverage. Now there's what's called an Independent Review Organization that you have to go through first. It says if youâ€™ve got a complaint with your insurance company
column19: you can take your complaint to an objective body. If the objective body rules on your behalf
column20: the insurance company must follow those rules. However
column21: if the insurance company doesn't follow the findings of the IRO
column22: then that becomes a cause of action in a court of law. It's time for our nation to come together and do what's right for the people
column23: and I think this is right for the people. You know
column24: I support a national patient's bill of rights
column26: and I want all people covered. I don't want the law to supersede good law like we've got in Texas. I think --

column1: Jim
column2: we have a direct disagreement on this.

column1: Absolutely not. I referred to the Dingle-Norwood bill. It is the bipartisan bill that is now pending in the Congress. The HMOs and the insurance companies support the other bill that's pending
column2: the one that the Republican majority has put forward. They like it because it doesn't accomplish what I think really needs to be accomplished to give the decisions back to the doctors and nurses and give you a right of appeal to somebody other than the HMO or insurance company
column3: let you go to the nearest emergency room without having to call an HMO before you call 911
column4: to let you see a specialist if you need to
column5: and it has strong bipartisan support. It is being blocked by the Republican leadership in the Congress.

column1: And I specifically would like to know whether Governor Bush will support the Dingle-Norwood bill
column2: which is the main one pending.

column1: Well
column2: the difference is is that I can get it done. That I can get something positive done on behalf of the people. That's what the question in this campaign is about. It's not only what's your philosophy and what's your position on issues
column3: but can you get things done? And I believe I can.

column1: What about the Dingle-Norwood bill?
I'm not quite through. Let me finish. I talked about the principles and the issues that I think are important in a patient's bill of rights. It's kind of Washington
column2: D.C. focus. Well
column3: it's in this committee or it's got this sponsor. If I'm the president
column4: we're going to have emergency room care
column5: we're going have gag orders
column6: we're going to have direct access to OB/GYN. People will be able to take their HMO insurance company to court. That's what I've done in Texas and that's the kind of leadership style I'll bring to Washington.

column3: 1)	" I'm glad you clarified that.

column1: Mr. Hankins
column2: I don't feel good about it
column3: and I think we ought to have a patient's bill of rights to take the medical decisions away from the HMOs and give them back to the doctors and nurses. I want to come back and tell you why
column4: but if you will forgive me
column5: I would like to say something right now at the beginning of this debate following on the moment of silence for Mel Carnahan and Randy Carnahan and Chris Sifford. Tipper and I were good friends with Mel and Randy
column6: and I know that all of us here want to extend our sympathy and condolences to Jean and the family and to the Sifford family. And I would just like to say that this debate in a way is a living tribute to Mel Carnahan because he loved the vigorous discussion of ideas in our democracy. He was a fantastic governor of Missouri. This state became one of the top five in the nation for health care coverage for children under his leadership. One of the best in advancing all kinds of benefits for children to grow up healthy and strong. And of course
column7: this debate also takes place at a time when the tragedy of the USS Cole is on our minds and hearts and insofar as the memorial service is tomorrow
column8: I would like to also extend sympathy to the families of those who have died and those who are still missing
column9: and the injured. Now
column10: Mr. Hankins
column11: I think that the situation that you describe has gotten completely out of hand. Doctors are giving prescriptions
column12: they're recommending treatments
column13: and then their recommendations are being overruled by HMOs and insurance companies. That is unacceptable. I support a strong national patient's bill of rights. It is actually a disagreement between us
column14: a national law that is pending on this
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill
column16: a bipartisan bill
column17: is one that I support and that the governor does not.

column1: I
column2: too
column3: want to extend my prayers and blessings
column4: God's blessings on the families whose lives were overturned yes -- tod -- last night. It's a tragic moment. Actually
column5: Mr. Vice President
column6: it's not true. I do support a national patient's bill of rights. As a matter of fact
column7: I brought Republicans and Democrats together to do just that in the State of Texas to get a patient's bill of rights through. It requires a different kind of leadership style to do it
column8: though. You see
column9: in order to get something done on behalf of the people
column10: you have to put partisanship aside
column11: and that's what we did in my state. We have one of the most advanced patient's bill of rights. It says
column12: for example
column13: that a woman doesn't have to go through a gate keeper to go to her gynecologist. It says that you can't gag a doctor
column14: doctor can advise you. The HMO
column15: the insurance company
column16: can't gag that doctor from giving you full advice. And this particular bill
column17: it allows patients to choose a doctor
column18: their own doctor if they want to. But we did something else that was interesting. We're one of the first states that said you can sue an HMO for denying you proper coverage. Now there's what's called an Independent Review Organization that you have to go through first. It says if youâ€™ve got a complaint with your insurance company
column19: you can take your complaint to an objective body. If the objective body rules on your behalf
column20: the insurance company must follow those rules. However
column21: if the insurance company doesn't follow the findings of the IRO
column22: then that becomes a cause of action in a court of law. It's time for our nation to come together and do what's right for the people
column23: and I think this is right for the people. You know
column24: I support a national patient's bill of rights
column26: and I want all people covered. I don't want the law to supersede good law like we've got in Texas. I think --

column1: Jim
column2: we have a direct disagreement on this.

column1: Absolutely not. I referred to the Dingle-Norwood bill. It is the bipartisan bill that is now pending in the Congress. The HMOs and the insurance companies support the other bill that's pending
column2: the one that the Republican majority has put forward. They like it because it doesn't accomplish what I think really needs to be accomplished to give the decisions back to the doctors and nurses and give you a right of appeal to somebody other than the HMO or insurance company
column3: let you go to the nearest emergency room without having to call an HMO before you call 911
column4: to let you see a specialist if you need to
column5: and it has strong bipartisan support. It is being blocked by the Republican leadership in the Congress.

column1: And I specifically would like to know whether Governor Bush will support the Dingle-Norwood bill
column2: which is the main one pending.

column1: Well
column2: the difference is is that I can get it done. That I can get something positive done on behalf of the people. That's what the question in this campaign is about. It's not only what's your philosophy and what's your position on issues
column3: but can you get things done? And I believe I can.

column1: What about the Dingle-Norwood bill?
I'm not quite through. Let me finish. I talked about the principles and the issues that I think are important in a patient's bill of rights. It's kind of Washington
column2: D.C. focus. Well
column3: it's in this committee or it's got this sponsor. If I'm the president
column4: we're going to have emergency room care
column5: we're going have gag orders
column6: we're going to have direct access to OB/GYN. People will be able to take their HMO insurance company to court. That's what I've done in Texas and that's the kind of leadership style I'll bring to Washington.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Joyce.

column1: Appreciate that question. Laura and I are proud parents of teenage girls
column2: twin daughters
column3: and I know what you're saying. Government ought to stand on the side of parents. Parents are teaching their children right from wrong
column4: and the message oftentimes gets undermined by the popular culture. You bet there's things that government can do. We can work with the entertainment industry to provide family hour. We can have filters on Internets where public money is spent. There ought to be filters in public libraries and filters in public schools so if kids get on the Internet
column5: there is not going to be pornography or violence coming in. I think we ought to have character education in our schools. I know that doesn't directly talk about Hollywood
column6: but it does reinforce the values you're teaching. Greatly expand character education funding so that public schools will teach children values
column7: values which have stood the test of time. There's afterschool money available. I think that afterschool money ought to be available for faith-based programs and charitable programs that exist because somebody has heard the call to love a neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself. That will help reinforce the values that parents teach at home as well. Ours is a great land
column8: and one of the reasons why is because we're free. And so I don't support censorship. But I do believe that we ought to talk plainly to the Hollywood moguls and people who produce this stuff and explain the consequences. I think we need to have rating systems that are clear. I happen to like the idea of having technology for the TV
column9: easy for parents to use so you can tune out these programs you don't want in your house. I'll remind mothers and dads the best weapon is the off/on button
column10: and paying attention to your children
column11: and eating dinner with them and being -- I'm sorry. I was on my peroration.

column1: My turn.
I care a lot about this. It's not just movies; television
column2: video games
column3: music
column4: the Internet. Parents now feel like you have to compete with the mass culture in order to raise your kids with the values that you want them to have. Tipper and I have four children. And God bless them
column5: every one of them decided on their own to come here this evening. I don't want to embarrass our oldest daughter. She and her husband made us grandparents almost a year-and-a-half ago
column6: and yet if she'll forgive me
column7: when she was little
column8: she brought a record home that had some awful lyrics in it and Tipper hit the ceiling. And that launched a campaign to try to get the record companies to put ratings that -- warning labels for parents. And I'm so proud of what she accomplished in getting them on there. I've been involved myself in negotiating and helping to move along the negotiations with the Internet service providers to get a parents' protection page every time 95% of the pages come up. And a feature that allows parents to automatically check with one click what sites your kids have visited lately. You know
column9: some parents are worried about those filters
column10: that you will have to ask your kids how to put them on there. But if you can check up on them
column11: that's real power. And recently the Federal Trade Commission pointed out that some of these entertainment companies have warned parents that the material is inappropriate for children
column12: and then they've turned around behind the backs of the parents and advertised that same adult material directly to children. That is an outrage. Joe Lieberman and I gave them six months to clean up their act. And if they don't do it
column13: we're gonna ask for tougher authority in the hands of the FTC on the false and deceptive advertising. I'll tell you this
column14: I want to do something about this. Respect the First Amendment
column15: but I will do something to help you raise your kids without that garbage.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Joyce.

column1: Appreciate that question. Laura and I are proud parents of teenage girls
column2: twin daughters
column3: and I know what you're saying. Government ought to stand on the side of parents. Parents are teaching their children right from wrong
column4: and the message oftentimes gets undermined by the popular culture. You bet there's things that government can do. We can work with the entertainment industry to provide family hour. We can have filters on Internets where public money is spent. There ought to be filters in public libraries and filters in public schools so if kids get on the Internet
column5: there is not going to be pornography or violence coming in. I think we ought to have character education in our schools. I know that doesn't directly talk about Hollywood
column6: but it does reinforce the values you're teaching. Greatly expand character education funding so that public schools will teach children values
column7: values which have stood the test of time. There's afterschool money available. I think that afterschool money ought to be available for faith-based programs and charitable programs that exist because somebody has heard the call to love a neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself. That will help reinforce the values that parents teach at home as well. Ours is a great land
column8: and one of the reasons why is because we're free. And so I don't support censorship. But I do believe that we ought to talk plainly to the Hollywood moguls and people who produce this stuff and explain the consequences. I think we need to have rating systems that are clear. I happen to like the idea of having technology for the TV
column9: easy for parents to use so you can tune out these programs you don't want in your house. I'll remind mothers and dads the best weapon is the off/on button
column10: and paying attention to your children
column11: and eating dinner with them and being -- I'm sorry. I was on my peroration.

column1: My turn.
I care a lot about this. It's not just movies; television
column2: video games
column3: music
column4: the Internet. Parents now feel like you have to compete with the mass culture in order to raise your kids with the values that you want them to have. Tipper and I have four children. And God bless them
column5: every one of them decided on their own to come here this evening. I don't want to embarrass our oldest daughter. She and her husband made us grandparents almost a year-and-a-half ago
column6: and yet if she'll forgive me
column7: when she was little
column8: she brought a record home that had some awful lyrics in it and Tipper hit the ceiling. And that launched a campaign to try to get the record companies to put ratings that -- warning labels for parents. And I'm so proud of what she accomplished in getting them on there. I've been involved myself in negotiating and helping to move along the negotiations with the Internet service providers to get a parents' protection page every time 95% of the pages come up. And a feature that allows parents to automatically check with one click what sites your kids have visited lately. You know
column9: some parents are worried about those filters
column10: that you will have to ask your kids how to put them on there. But if you can check up on them
column11: that's real power. And recently the Federal Trade Commission pointed out that some of these entertainment companies have warned parents that the material is inappropriate for children
column12: and then they've turned around behind the backs of the parents and advertised that same adult material directly to children. That is an outrage. Joe Lieberman and I gave them six months to clean up their act. And if they don't do it
column13: we're gonna ask for tougher authority in the hands of the FTC on the false and deceptive advertising. I'll tell you this
column14: I want to do something about this. Respect the First Amendment
column15: but I will do something to help you raise your kids without that garbage.

column1: Appreciate that question. Laura and I are proud parents of teenage girls
column2: twin daughters
column3: and I know what you're saying. Government ought to stand on the side of parents. Parents are teaching their children right from wrong
column4: and the message oftentimes gets undermined by the popular culture. You bet there's things that government can do. We can work with the entertainment industry to provide family hour. We can have filters on Internets where public money is spent. There ought to be filters in public libraries and filters in public schools so if kids get on the Internet
column5: there is not going to be pornography or violence coming in. I think we ought to have character education in our schools. I know that doesn't directly talk about Hollywood
column6: but it does reinforce the values you're teaching. Greatly expand character education funding so that public schools will teach children values
column7: values which have stood the test of time. There's afterschool money available. I think that afterschool money ought to be available for faith-based programs and charitable programs that exist because somebody has heard the call to love a neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself. That will help reinforce the values that parents teach at home as well. Ours is a great land
column8: and one of the reasons why is because we're free. And so I don't support censorship. But I do believe that we ought to talk plainly to the Hollywood moguls and people who produce this stuff and explain the consequences. I think we need to have rating systems that are clear. I happen to like the idea of having technology for the TV
column9: easy for parents to use so you can tune out these programs you don't want in your house. I'll remind mothers and dads the best weapon is the off/on button
column10: and paying attention to your children
column11: and eating dinner with them and being -- I'm sorry. I was on my peroration.

I care a lot about this. It's not just movies; television
column2: video games
column3: music
column4: the Internet. Parents now feel like you have to compete with the mass culture in order to raise your kids with the values that you want them to have. Tipper and I have four children. And God bless them

column6: and yet if she'll forgive me
column7: when she was little
column8: she brought a record home that had some awful lyrics in it and Tipper hit the ceiling. And that launched a campaign to try to get the record companies to put ratings that -- warning labels for parents. And I'm so proud of what she accomplished in getting them on there. I've been involved myself in negotiating and helping to move along the negotiations with the Internet service providers to get a parents' protection page every time 95% of the pages come up. And a feature that allows parents to automatically check with one click what sites your kids have visited lately. You know
column9: some parents are worried about those filters
column10: that you will have to ask your kids how to put them on there. But if you can check up on them
column11: that's real power. And recently the Federal Trade Commission pointed out that some of these entertainment companies have warned parents that the material is inappropriate for children
column12: and then they've turned around behind the backs of the parents and advertised that same adult material directly to children. That is an outrage. Joe Lieberman and I gave them six months to clean up their act. And if they don't do it

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Joyce.

column1: Appreciate that question. Laura and I are proud parents of teenage girls
column2: twin daughters
column3: and I know what you're saying. Government ought to stand on the side of parents. Parents are teaching their children right from wrong
column4: and the message oftentimes gets undermined by the popular culture. You bet there's things that government can do. We can work with the entertainment industry to provide family hour. We can have filters on Internets where public money is spent. There ought to be filters in public libraries and filters in public schools so if kids get on the Internet
column5: there is not going to be pornography or violence coming in. I think we ought to have character education in our schools. I know that doesn't directly talk about Hollywood
column6: but it does reinforce the values you're teaching. Greatly expand character education funding so that public schools will teach children values
column7: values which have stood the test of time. There's afterschool money available. I think that afterschool money ought to be available for faith-based programs and charitable programs that exist because somebody has heard the call to love a neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself. That will help reinforce the values that parents teach at home as well. Ours is a great land
column8: and one of the reasons why is because we're free. And so I don't support censorship. But I do believe that we ought to talk plainly to the Hollywood moguls and people who produce this stuff and explain the consequences. I think we need to have rating systems that are clear. I happen to like the idea of having technology for the TV
column9: easy for parents to use so you can tune out these programs you don't want in your house. I'll remind mothers and dads the best weapon is the off/on button
column10: and paying attention to your children
column11: and eating dinner with them and being -- I'm sorry. I was on my peroration.

column1: My turn.
I care a lot about this. It's not just movies; television
column2: video games
column3: music
column4: the Internet. Parents now feel like you have to compete with the mass culture in order to raise your kids with the values that you want them to have. Tipper and I have four children. And God bless them
column5: every one of them decided on their own to come here this evening. I don't want to embarrass our oldest daughter. She and her husband made us grandparents almost a year-and-a-half ago
column6: and yet if she'll forgive me
column7: when she was little
column8: she brought a record home that had some awful lyrics in it and Tipper hit the ceiling. And that launched a campaign to try to get the record companies to put ratings that -- warning labels for parents. And I'm so proud of what she accomplished in getting them on there. I've been involved myself in negotiating and helping to move along the negotiations with the Internet service providers to get a parents' protection page every time 95% of the pages come up. And a feature that allows parents to automatically check with one click what sites your kids have visited lately. You know
column9: some parents are worried about those filters
column10: that you will have to ask your kids how to put them on there. But if you can check up on them
column11: that's real power. And recently the Federal Trade Commission pointed out that some of these entertainment companies have warned parents that the material is inappropriate for children
column12: and then they've turned around behind the backs of the parents and advertised that same adult material directly to children. That is an outrage. Joe Lieberman and I gave them six months to clean up their act. And if they don't do it
column13: we're gonna ask for tougher authority in the hands of the FTC on the false and deceptive advertising. I'll tell you this
column14: I want to do something about this. Respect the First Amendment
column15: but I will do something to help you raise your kids without that garbage.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 11)	" Right next to the last.

column1: We've got to change it. I spend a good deal of time talking to young people
column2: and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying
column3: I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience. And I want to tell you what I tell them. Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams
column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: Tell you what I hear. A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington
column2: D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics. They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another. There's a lot of young folks saying
column3: you know
column4: why do I want to be involved with this mess? And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight
column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run
column10: I had to resolve two issues in my mind. One
column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington
column12: D.C. And I believe the answer is yes
column13: otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote. That's what happened in Texas. We worked together. There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga. He is the chairman of the health committee. He came here for a reason
column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington
column15: D.C. needs. And finally
column16: sir
column17: to answer your question
column18: you need somebody in office who will tell the truth. That's the best way to get people back in the system.

column1: We've got to change it. I spend a good deal of time talking to young people
column2: and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying
column3: I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience. And I want to tell you what I tell them. Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams
column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: Tell you what I hear. A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington
column2: D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics. They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another. There's a lot of young folks saying
column3: you know
column4: why do I want to be involved with this mess? And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight
column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run
column10: I had to resolve two issues in my mind. One
column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington
column12: D.C. And I believe the answer is yes
column13: otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote. That's what happened in Texas. We worked together. There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga. He is the chairman of the health committee. He came here for a reason
column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington
column15: D.C. needs. And finally
column16: sir
column17: to answer your question
column18: you need somebody in office who will tell the truth. That's the best way to get people back in the system.

column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs

column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support

column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: We've got to change it. I spend a good deal of time talking to young people
column2: and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying
column3: I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience. And I want to tell you what I tell them. Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams
column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: Tell you what I hear. A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington
column2: D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics. They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another. There's a lot of young folks saying
column3: you know
column4: why do I want to be involved with this mess? And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight
column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run
column10: I had to resolve two issues in my mind. One
column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington
column12: D.C. And I believe the answer is yes
column13: otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote. That's what happened in Texas. We worked together. There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga. He is the chairman of the health committee. He came here for a reason
column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington
column15: D.C. needs. And finally
column16: sir
column17: to answer your question
column18: you need somebody in office who will tell the truth. That's the best way to get people back in the system.

column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column3: you know

column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run

column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington

column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington

column1: We've got to change it. I spend a good deal of time talking to young people
column2: and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying
column3: I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience. And I want to tell you what I tell them. Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams
column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: Tell you what I hear. A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington
column2: D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics. They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another. There's a lot of young folks saying
column3: you know
column4: why do I want to be involved with this mess? And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight
column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run
column10: I had to resolve two issues in my mind. One
column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington
column12: D.C. And I believe the answer is yes
column13: otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote. That's what happened in Texas. We worked together. There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga. He is the chairman of the health committee. He came here for a reason
column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington
column15: D.C. needs. And finally
column16: sir
column17: to answer your question
column18: you need somebody in office who will tell the truth. That's the best way to get people back in the system.

column1: We've got to change it. I spend a good deal of time talking to young people
column2: and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying
column3: I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience. And I want to tell you what I tell them. Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams
column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: Tell you what I hear. A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington
column2: D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics. They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another. There's a lot of young folks saying
column3: you know
column4: why do I want to be involved with this mess? And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight
column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run
column10: I had to resolve two issues in my mind. One
column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington
column12: D.C. And I believe the answer is yes
column13: otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote. That's what happened in Texas. We worked together. There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga. He is the chairman of the health committee. He came here for a reason
column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington
column15: D.C. needs. And finally
column16: sir
column17: to answer your question
column18: you need somebody in office who will tell the truth. That's the best way to get people back in the system.

column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now

column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: We've got to change it. I spend a good deal of time talking to young people
column2: and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying
column3: I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience. And I want to tell you what I tell them. Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams
column4: as young people do
column5: are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle
column6: and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe
column7: then they're gonna be let down and disappointed. But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union. We're America
column8: and we believe in our future and we know we have the ability to shape our future. Now
column9: we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy. And that is the current campaign financing system. And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls. I don't believe that's a fair measure. I'm telling you
column10: I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president. Governor Bush opposes it. I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that. Because I think that the special interests have too much power
column11: and we need to give our democracy back to the American people. Let me tell you why. Those issues you mentioned
column12: Social Security
column13: prescription drugs
column14: the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made. The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill
column15: the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support
column16: and that Gov. Bush does not support. The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel. They ought to have their voices heard
column17: but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people. We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are. And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be. We can.

column1: Tell you what I hear. A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington
column2: D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics. They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another. There's a lot of young folks saying
column3: you know
column4: why do I want to be involved with this mess? And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight
column5: is to set aside the partisan differences
column6: and set an agenda that will make sense. Medicare
column7: I know you talked about it
column8: but Medicare is relevant for all of us
column9: young and old alike. We better get it right now. Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike. I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off. I think it's the tone. I think it's the attitude. I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way. Before I decided to run
column10: I had to resolve two issues in my mind. One
column11: could our family endure all this business. And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it. The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington
column12: D.C. And I believe the answer is yes
column13: otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote. That's what happened in Texas. We worked together. There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga. He is the chairman of the health committee. He came here for a reason
column14: to tout our record on health in Texas. He's a Democrat. I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat. What I cared about is could we work together. That's what Washington
column15: D.C. needs. And finally
column16: sir
column17: to answer your question
column18: you need somebody in office who will tell the truth. That's the best way to get people back in the system.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Norma.

column1: I've had a record of bringing people from all walks of life into my administration
column2: and my administration is better off for it in Texas. I'm going to find people that want to serve their country. But I want a diverse administration
column3: I think it's important. I've worked hard in the State of Texas to make sure our institutions reflect the state with good
column4: smart policy. Policy that rejects quotas. I don't like quotas. Quotas tend to pit one group of people against another. Quotas are bad for America. It's not the way America is all about. But policies that give people a helping hand so they can help themselves. For example
column5: in our State of Texas I worked with the legislature
column6: both Republicans and Democrats
column7: to pass a law that said if you come in the top 10% of your high school class
column8: you're automatically admitted to one of our higher institutions of learning
column9: college. And as a result
column10: our universities are now more diverse. It was a smart thing to do. What I called it
column11: I labeled it affirmative access. I think the contracting business in government can help. Not with quotas
column12: but help meet a goal of ownership of small businesses
column13: for example. The contracts need to be smaller
column14: the agencies need to be -- need to recruit and to work hard to find people to bid on the state contracts. I think we can do that in a way that represents what America is all about
column15: which is equal opportunity and an opportunity for people to realize their potential. So to answer your question
column16: I support
column17: I guess the way to put it
column18: is affirmative access. I'll have an administration that will make you proud. Thank you.

column1: I believe in this goal and effort with all my heart. I believe that our future as a nation depends upon whether or not we can break down these barriers that have been used to pit group against group
column2: and bring our people together. How do you do it? Well
column3: you establish respect for differences. You don't ignore differences. It's all too easy for somebody in the majority in the population to say oh
column4: we're just all the same
column5: without an understanding of the different life experience that you've had
column6: that others have had. Once you have that understanding and mutual respect
column7: then we can transcend the differences and embrace the highest common denominator of the American spirit. I don't know what affirmative access means. I do know what affirmative action means. I know the governor is against it
column8: and I know that I'm for it. I know what a hate crime statute pending at the national level is all about in the aftermath of James Byrd's death. I'm for that proposed law
column9: the governor is against it. I know what it means to have a commitment to diversity. I am part of an administration that has the finest record on diversity. And incidentally
column10: an excellent -- I mean
column11: I think our success over the last eight years has not been in spite of diversity but because of it. Because we're able to draw on the wisdom and experience from different parts of the society that hadn't been tapped in the same way before. And incidentally
column12: Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri. And I want to honor that among his other achievements here. Now
column13: I just believe that what we have to do is enforce the civil rights laws. I'm against quotas. This is
column14: with all due respect
column15: Governor
column16: that's a red herring. Affirmative action isn't quotas. I'm against quotas
column17: they're illegal. They're against the American way. Affirmative action means that you take extra steps to acknowledge the history of discrimination and injustice and prejudice and bring all people into the American dream because it helps everybody
column18: not just those who are directly benefitting.

column1: If affirmative action means quotas
column2: I'm against it. If affirmative action means what I just described what I'm for
column3: then I'm for it. You heard what I was for. The vice president keeps saying I'm against things. You heard what I was for
column4: and that's what I support.

column1: He said if affirmative action means quotas
column2: he's against it. Affirmative action doesn't mean quotas. Are you for it without quotas?

column1: I may not be for your version
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: but I'm for what I just described to the lady.

column1: Are you for what the Supreme Court says is a constitutional way of having affirmative action?
I think that speaks for itself.
No
column2: it doesn't speak for itself
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: it speaks for the fact that there are certain rules in this that we all agree to
column5: but evidently rules don't mean anything.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Norma.

column1: I've had a record of bringing people from all walks of life into my administration
column2: and my administration is better off for it in Texas. I'm going to find people that want to serve their country. But I want a diverse administration
column3: I think it's important. I've worked hard in the State of Texas to make sure our institutions reflect the state with good
column4: smart policy. Policy that rejects quotas. I don't like quotas. Quotas tend to pit one group of people against another. Quotas are bad for America. It's not the way America is all about. But policies that give people a helping hand so they can help themselves. For example
column5: in our State of Texas I worked with the legislature
column6: both Republicans and Democrats
column7: to pass a law that said if you come in the top 10% of your high school class
column8: you're automatically admitted to one of our higher institutions of learning
column9: college. And as a result
column10: our universities are now more diverse. It was a smart thing to do. What I called it
column11: I labeled it affirmative access. I think the contracting business in government can help. Not with quotas
column12: but help meet a goal of ownership of small businesses
column13: for example. The contracts need to be smaller
column14: the agencies need to be -- need to recruit and to work hard to find people to bid on the state contracts. I think we can do that in a way that represents what America is all about
column15: which is equal opportunity and an opportunity for people to realize their potential. So to answer your question
column16: I support
column17: I guess the way to put it
column18: is affirmative access. I'll have an administration that will make you proud. Thank you.

column1: I believe in this goal and effort with all my heart. I believe that our future as a nation depends upon whether or not we can break down these barriers that have been used to pit group against group
column2: and bring our people together. How do you do it? Well
column3: you establish respect for differences. You don't ignore differences. It's all too easy for somebody in the majority in the population to say oh
column4: we're just all the same
column5: without an understanding of the different life experience that you've had
column6: that others have had. Once you have that understanding and mutual respect
column7: then we can transcend the differences and embrace the highest common denominator of the American spirit. I don't know what affirmative access means. I do know what affirmative action means. I know the governor is against it
column8: and I know that I'm for it. I know what a hate crime statute pending at the national level is all about in the aftermath of James Byrd's death. I'm for that proposed law
column9: the governor is against it. I know what it means to have a commitment to diversity. I am part of an administration that has the finest record on diversity. And incidentally
column10: an excellent -- I mean
column11: I think our success over the last eight years has not been in spite of diversity but because of it. Because we're able to draw on the wisdom and experience from different parts of the society that hadn't been tapped in the same way before. And incidentally
column12: Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri. And I want to honor that among his other achievements here. Now
column13: I just believe that what we have to do is enforce the civil rights laws. I'm against quotas. This is
column14: with all due respect
column15: Governor
column16: that's a red herring. Affirmative action isn't quotas. I'm against quotas
column17: they're illegal. They're against the American way. Affirmative action means that you take extra steps to acknowledge the history of discrimination and injustice and prejudice and bring all people into the American dream because it helps everybody
column18: not just those who are directly benefitting.

column1: If affirmative action means quotas
column2: I'm against it. If affirmative action means what I just described what I'm for
column3: then I'm for it. You heard what I was for. The vice president keeps saying I'm against things. You heard what I was for
column4: and that's what I support.

column1: He said if affirmative action means quotas
column2: he's against it. Affirmative action doesn't mean quotas. Are you for it without quotas?

column1: I may not be for your version
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: but I'm for what I just described to the lady.

column1: Are you for what the Supreme Court says is a constitutional way of having affirmative action?
I think that speaks for itself.
No
column2: it doesn't speak for itself
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: it speaks for the fact that there are certain rules in this that we all agree to
column5: but evidently rules don't mean anything.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Norma.

column1: I've had a record of bringing people from all walks of life into my administration
column2: and my administration is better off for it in Texas. I'm going to find people that want to serve their country. But I want a diverse administration
column3: I think it's important. I've worked hard in the State of Texas to make sure our institutions reflect the state with good
column4: smart policy. Policy that rejects quotas. I don't like quotas. Quotas tend to pit one group of people against another. Quotas are bad for America. It's not the way America is all about. But policies that give people a helping hand so they can help themselves. For example
column5: in our State of Texas I worked with the legislature
column6: both Republicans and Democrats
column7: to pass a law that said if you come in the top 10% of your high school class
column8: you're automatically admitted to one of our higher institutions of learning
column9: college. And as a result
column10: our universities are now more diverse. It was a smart thing to do. What I called it
column11: I labeled it affirmative access. I think the contracting business in government can help. Not with quotas
column12: but help meet a goal of ownership of small businesses
column13: for example. The contracts need to be smaller
column14: the agencies need to be -- need to recruit and to work hard to find people to bid on the state contracts. I think we can do that in a way that represents what America is all about
column15: which is equal opportunity and an opportunity for people to realize their potential. So to answer your question
column16: I support
column17: I guess the way to put it
column18: is affirmative access. I'll have an administration that will make you proud. Thank you.

column1: I believe in this goal and effort with all my heart. I believe that our future as a nation depends upon whether or not we can break down these barriers that have been used to pit group against group
column2: and bring our people together. How do you do it? Well
column3: you establish respect for differences. You don't ignore differences. It's all too easy for somebody in the majority in the population to say oh
column4: we're just all the same
column5: without an understanding of the different life experience that you've had
column6: that others have had. Once you have that understanding and mutual respect
column7: then we can transcend the differences and embrace the highest common denominator of the American spirit. I don't know what affirmative access means. I do know what affirmative action means. I know the governor is against it
column8: and I know that I'm for it. I know what a hate crime statute pending at the national level is all about in the aftermath of James Byrd's death. I'm for that proposed law
column9: the governor is against it. I know what it means to have a commitment to diversity. I am part of an administration that has the finest record on diversity. And incidentally
column10: an excellent -- I mean
column11: I think our success over the last eight years has not been in spite of diversity but because of it. Because we're able to draw on the wisdom and experience from different parts of the society that hadn't been tapped in the same way before. And incidentally
column12: Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri. And I want to honor that among his other achievements here. Now
column13: I just believe that what we have to do is enforce the civil rights laws. I'm against quotas. This is
column14: with all due respect
column15: Governor
column16: that's a red herring. Affirmative action isn't quotas. I'm against quotas
column17: they're illegal. They're against the American way. Affirmative action means that you take extra steps to acknowledge the history of discrimination and injustice and prejudice and bring all people into the American dream because it helps everybody
column18: not just those who are directly benefitting.

column1: If affirmative action means quotas
column2: I'm against it. If affirmative action means what I just described what I'm for
column3: then I'm for it. You heard what I was for. The vice president keeps saying I'm against things. You heard what I was for
column4: and that's what I support.

column1: He said if affirmative action means quotas
column2: he's against it. Affirmative action doesn't mean quotas. Are you for it without quotas?

column1: I may not be for your version
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: but I'm for what I just described to the lady.

column1: Are you for what the Supreme Court says is a constitutional way of having affirmative action?
I think that speaks for itself.
No
column2: it doesn't speak for itself
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: it speaks for the fact that there are certain rules in this that we all agree to
column5: but evidently rules don't mean anything.

column1: And incidentally, Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri. And I want to honor that among his other achievements here.
