column1: I believe in this goal and effort with all my heart. I believe that our future as a nation depends upon whether or not we can break down these barriers that have been used to pit group against group
column2: and bring our people together. How do you do it? Well
column3: you establish respect for differences. You don't ignore differences. It's all too easy for somebody in the majority in the population to say oh
column4: we're just all the same
column5: without an understanding of the different life experience that you've had
column6: that others have had. Once you have that understanding and mutual respect
column7: then we can transcend the differences and embrace the highest common denominator of the American spirit. I don't know what affirmative access means. I do know what affirmative action means. I know the governor is against it
column8: and I know that I'm for it. I know what a hate crime statute pending at the national level is all about in the aftermath of James Byrd's death. I'm for that proposed law
column9: the governor is against it. I know what it means to have a commitment to diversity. I am part of an administration that has the finest record on diversity. And incidentally
column10: an excellent -- I mean
column11: I think our success over the last eight years has not been in spite of diversity but because of it. Because we're able to draw on the wisdom and experience from different parts of the society that hadn't been tapped in the same way before. And incidentally
column12: Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri. And I want to honor that among his other achievements here. Now
column13: I just believe that what we have to do is enforce the civil rights laws. I'm against quotas. This is
column14: with all due respect
column15: Governor
column16: that's a red herring. Affirmative action isn't quotas. I'm against quotas
column17: they're illegal. They're against the American way. Affirmative action means that you take extra steps to acknowledge the history of discrimination and injustice and prejudice and bring all people into the American dream because it helps everybody
column18: not just those who are directly benefitting.

column1: If affirmative action means quotas
column2: I'm against it. If affirmative action means what I just described what I'm for
column3: then I'm for it. You heard what I was for. The vice president keeps saying I'm against things. You heard what I was for
column4: and that's what I support.

column1: He said if affirmative action means quotas
column2: he's against it. Affirmative action doesn't mean quotas. Are you for it without quotas?

column1: I may not be for your version
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: but I'm for what I just described to the lady.

column1: Are you for what the Supreme Court says is a constitutional way of having affirmative action?
I think that speaks for itself.
No
column2: it doesn't speak for itself
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: it speaks for the fact that there are certain rules in this that we all agree to
column5: but evidently rules don't mean anything.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: Norma.

column1: I've had a record of bringing people from all walks of life into my administration
column2: and my administration is better off for it in Texas. I'm going to find people that want to serve their country. But I want a diverse administration
column3: I think it's important. I've worked hard in the State of Texas to make sure our institutions reflect the state with good
column4: smart policy. Policy that rejects quotas. I don't like quotas. Quotas tend to pit one group of people against another. Quotas are bad for America. It's not the way America is all about. But policies that give people a helping hand so they can help themselves. For example
column5: in our State of Texas I worked with the legislature
column6: both Republicans and Democrats
column7: to pass a law that said if you come in the top 10% of your high school class
column8: you're automatically admitted to one of our higher institutions of learning
column9: college. And as a result
column10: our universities are now more diverse. It was a smart thing to do. What I called it
column11: I labeled it affirmative access. I think the contracting business in government can help. Not with quotas
column12: but help meet a goal of ownership of small businesses
column13: for example. The contracts need to be smaller
column14: the agencies need to be -- need to recruit and to work hard to find people to bid on the state contracts. I think we can do that in a way that represents what America is all about
column15: which is equal opportunity and an opportunity for people to realize their potential. So to answer your question
column16: I support
column17: I guess the way to put it
column18: is affirmative access. I'll have an administration that will make you proud. Thank you.

column1: I believe in this goal and effort with all my heart. I believe that our future as a nation depends upon whether or not we can break down these barriers that have been used to pit group against group
column2: and bring our people together. How do you do it? Well
column3: you establish respect for differences. You don't ignore differences. It's all too easy for somebody in the majority in the population to say oh
column4: we're just all the same
column5: without an understanding of the different life experience that you've had
column6: that others have had. Once you have that understanding and mutual respect
column7: then we can transcend the differences and embrace the highest common denominator of the American spirit. I don't know what affirmative access means. I do know what affirmative action means. I know the governor is against it
column8: and I know that I'm for it. I know what a hate crime statute pending at the national level is all about in the aftermath of James Byrd's death. I'm for that proposed law
column9: the governor is against it. I know what it means to have a commitment to diversity. I am part of an administration that has the finest record on diversity. And incidentally
column10: an excellent -- I mean
column11: I think our success over the last eight years has not been in spite of diversity but because of it. Because we're able to draw on the wisdom and experience from different parts of the society that hadn't been tapped in the same way before. And incidentally
column12: Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri. And I want to honor that among his other achievements here. Now
column13: I just believe that what we have to do is enforce the civil rights laws. I'm against quotas. This is
column14: with all due respect
column15: Governor
column16: that's a red herring. Affirmative action isn't quotas. I'm against quotas
column17: they're illegal. They're against the American way. Affirmative action means that you take extra steps to acknowledge the history of discrimination and injustice and prejudice and bring all people into the American dream because it helps everybody
column18: not just those who are directly benefitting.

column1: If affirmative action means quotas
column2: I'm against it. If affirmative action means what I just described what I'm for
column3: then I'm for it. You heard what I was for. The vice president keeps saying I'm against things. You heard what I was for
column4: and that's what I support.

column1: He said if affirmative action means quotas
column2: he's against it. Affirmative action doesn't mean quotas. Are you for it without quotas?

column1: I may not be for your version
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: but I'm for what I just described to the lady.

column1: Are you for what the Supreme Court says is a constitutional way of having affirmative action?
I think that speaks for itself.
No
column2: it doesn't speak for itself
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: it speaks for the fact that there are certain rules in this that we all agree to
column5: but evidently rules don't mean anything.

column2: '17Oct'
column4: I'm not proud of that. The death penalty is a very serious business
column5: Leo. It's an issue that good people obviously disagree on. I take my job seriously. And if you think I was proud of it
column6: I think you misread me
column7: I do. I was sworn to uphold the laws of my state. During the course of the campaign in 1994 I was asked do you support the death penalty. I said I did if administered fairly and justly. Because I believe it saves lives
column8: Leo
column9: I do. If it's administered swiftly
column10: justly and fairly
column11: it saves lives. One of the things that happens when you're a governor
column12: at least oftentimes you have to make tough decisions. You can't let public persuasion sway you
column13: because the job is to enforce the law. And that's what I did
column14: sir. There have been some tough cases come across my desk. Some of the hardest moments since I've been the governor of the State of Texas is to deal with those cases. But my job is to ask two questions
column15: sir. Is the person guilty of the crime? And did the person have full access to the courts of law? And I can tell you looking at you right now
column16: in all cases those answers were affirmative. I'm not proud of any record. I'm proud of the fact that violent crime is down in the State of Texas. I'm proud of the fact that we hold people accountable. But I'm not proud of any record
column17: sir
column18: I'm not.

column1: I support the death penalty. I think that it has to be administered not only fairly with attention to things like DNA evidence
column2: which I think should be used in all capital cases
column3: but also with very careful attention. If
column4: for example
column5: somebody confesses to the crime and somebody is waiting on death row
column6: there has to be alertness to say wait a minute
column7: have we got the wrong guy? If the wrong guy is put to death
column8: then that's a double tragedy. Not only has an innocent person been executed
column9: but the real perpetrator of the crime has not been held accountable for it. And in some cases may be still at large. But I support the death penalty in the most heinous cases.

column1: I do. It's the only reason to be for it. Let me finish
column2: sir. I don't think you should support the death penalty to seek revenge. I don't think that's right. I think the reason to support the death penalty is because it saves other people's lives.

column1: I think it is a deterrent. I know that's a controversial view
column2: but I do believe it's a deterrent.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 15)	" Yes. (LAUGHTER) I am a person who keeps promises. And
column4: you know
column5: we've heard a lot about -- from the governor about not much being done in the last eight years
column6: as if the promises that I made eight years ago have not been kept. I think the record shows otherwise. We have gone from the biggest deficits eight years ago to the biggest surpluses in history today. Instead of high unemployment
column7: we now have the lowest African-American unemployment
column8: the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured. 22 million new jobs
column9: very low unemployment nationally. Instead of ballooning the debt and multiplying it four times over
column10: we have seen the debt actually begun to be paid down. Here are some promises that I'll make to you now. I will balance the budget every year. I will pay down the debt every year. I will give middle-class Americans tax cuts
column11: meaningful ones. And I will invest in education
column12: health care
column13: protecting the environment and retirement security. We both made promises in this campaign. I promise you I will keep mine. Let me tell you about one of the governor's. He has promised a trillion dollars out of the Social Security Trust Fund for young working adults to invest and save on their own. But he's promised seniors that their Social Security benefits will not be cut
column14: and he's promised the same trillion dollars to them. So this is a show me state. Reminds me of the line from the movie
column15: ""Show me the money."" Which one of those promises will you keep and which will you break
column16: Governor?

column1: Thank you for your question. (LAUGHTER) I -- there's an old high school debating trick
column2: which is to answer something and then attack your opponent at the end. You asked about promises. You were promised that Medicare would be reformed
column3: and that Social Security would be reformed. You were promised a middle-class tax cut in 1992. It didn't happen. There's too much bitterness in Washington. There's too much wrangling. It's time to have a fresh start. One of the reasons I was successful as the governor of Texas is because I didn't try to be all things to all people. When I campaigned in a race
column4: a lot of folks didn't think I could win including
column5: by the way
column6: my mother. (LAUGHTER) I said I'd do four things; tort reform
column7: education reform
column8: welfare reform and juvenile justice reform. And I won. And I had the will of the people in my state behind me. And then I brought folks together to get it done. And that's what we need
column9: I think
column10: in this election. To me that's what it's all about. I'm sure your 6th grade kids are listening and saying
column11: these guys will say anything to get elected. But there's a record
column12: and that's what I hope people look at. One of my promises is going to be Social Security reform
column13: and you bet
column14: we need to take a trillion dollars out of that $2.4 trillion surplus. Now remember
column15: Social Security revenue exceeds expenses up until 2015. People are going to get paid. But if you're a younger worker
column16: if you're younger
column17: you better hope this country thinks differently
column18: otherwise you're gonna be faced with huge payroll taxes or reduced benefits. And you bet we're gonna take a trillion dollars of your own money and let you invest it under safe guidelines so you get a better rate of return on the money than the paltry 2% that the federal government gets for you today. That's one of my promises. But it's gonna require people to bring both Republicans and Democrats together to get it done. That's what it requires. There was a chance to get this done. It was a bipartisan approach
column19: but it's been rejected. I'm going to bring them together.

column1: Well
column2: first of all
column3: Jim
column4: I would like to respond to what the governor just said. Because the trillion dollars that has been promised to young people has also been promised to older people. And you cannot keep both promises. If you're in your mid-40's under the governor's plan
column5: Social Security will be bankrupt by the time you retire
column6: if he takes it out of the Social Security Trust Fund. Under my plan it will be -- its solvency will be extended until you're 100. Now that is the difference. And the governor may not want to answer that question
column7: he may want to call it a high school debating trick
column8: but let me tell you this. This election is not about debating tricks
column9: it is about your future. The reason Social Security -- he says it gets 2%. You know
column10: it's not a bank account that just pays back money that's invested. It is also used to give your mothers and fathers the Social Security checks that they live on. If you take a trillion dollars out of that Social Security Trust Fund
column11: how are the checks going to be -- how are you going to keep faith with the seniors? Now let me come directly to your question.

column1: Well
column2: can I answer that? One reason people are skeptical is because people don't answer the questions they've been asked. The trillion dollars comes out of the surplus so that you can invest some of your own money. There's just a difference of opinion. I want workers to have their own assets. It's who you trust
column3: government or people.

column6: my mother. (LAUGHTER) I said I'd do four things; tort reform
column7: education reform
column8: welfare reform and juvenile justice reform. And I won. And I had the will of the people in my state behind me. And then I brought folks together to get it done. And that's what we need
column9: I think
column10: in this election. To me that's what it's all about. I'm sure your 6th grade kids are listening and saying
column11: these guys will say anything to get elected. But there's a record
column12: and that's what I hope people look at. One of my promises is going to be Social Security reform
column13: and you bet
column14: we need to take a trillion dollars out of that $2.4 trillion surplus. Now remember
column15: Social Security revenue exceeds expenses up until 2015. People are going to get paid. But if you're a younger worker
column16: if you're younger
column17: you better hope this country thinks differently
column18: otherwise you're gonna be faced with huge payroll taxes or reduced benefits. And you bet we're gonna take a trillion dollars of your own money and let you invest it under safe guidelines so you get a better rate of return on the money than the paltry 2% that the federal government gets for you today. That's one of my promises. But it's gonna require people to bring both Republicans and Democrats together to get it done. That's what it requires. There was a chance to get this done. It was a bipartisan approach
column19: but it's been rejected. I'm going to bring them together.

column1: Well
column2: first of all
column3: Jim
column4: I would like to respond to what the governor just said. Because the trillion dollars that has been promised to young people has also been promised to older people. And you cannot keep both promises. If you're in your mid-40's under the governor's plan
column5: Social Security will be bankrupt by the time you retire
column6: if he takes it out of the Social Security Trust Fund. Under my plan it will be -- its solvency will be extended until you're 100. Now that is the difference. And the governor may not want to answer that question
column7: he may want to call it a high school debating trick
column8: but let me tell you this. This election is not about debating tricks
column9: it is about your future. The reason Social Security -- he says it gets 2%. You know
column10: it's not a bank account that just pays back money that's invested. It is also used to give your mothers and fathers the Social Security checks that they live on. If you take a trillion dollars out of that Social Security Trust Fund
column11: how are the checks going to be -- how are you going to keep faith with the seniors? Now let me come directly to your question.

column1: Well
column2: can I answer that? One reason people are skeptical is because people don't answer the questions they've been asked. The trillion dollars comes out of the surplus so that you can invest some of your own money. There's just a difference of opinion. I want workers to have their own assets. It's who you trust
column3: government or people.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 15)	" Yes. (LAUGHTER) I am a person who keeps promises. And
column4: you know
column5: we've heard a lot about -- from the governor about not much being done in the last eight years
column6: as if the promises that I made eight years ago have not been kept. I think the record shows otherwise. We have gone from the biggest deficits eight years ago to the biggest surpluses in history today. Instead of high unemployment
column7: we now have the lowest African-American unemployment
column8: the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured. 22 million new jobs
column9: very low unemployment nationally. Instead of ballooning the debt and multiplying it four times over
column10: we have seen the debt actually begun to be paid down. Here are some promises that I'll make to you now. I will balance the budget every year. I will pay down the debt every year. I will give middle-class Americans tax cuts
column11: meaningful ones. And I will invest in education
column12: health care
column13: protecting the environment and retirement security. We both made promises in this campaign. I promise you I will keep mine. Let me tell you about one of the governor's. He has promised a trillion dollars out of the Social Security Trust Fund for young working adults to invest and save on their own. But he's promised seniors that their Social Security benefits will not be cut
column14: and he's promised the same trillion dollars to them. So this is a show me state. Reminds me of the line from the movie
column15: ""Show me the money."" Which one of those promises will you keep and which will you break
column16: Governor?

column1: Thank you for your question. (LAUGHTER) I -- there's an old high school debating trick
column2: which is to answer something and then attack your opponent at the end. You asked about promises. You were promised that Medicare would be reformed
column3: and that Social Security would be reformed. You were promised a middle-class tax cut in 1992. It didn't happen. There's too much bitterness in Washington. There's too much wrangling. It's time to have a fresh start. One of the reasons I was successful as the governor of Texas is because I didn't try to be all things to all people. When I campaigned in a race
column4: a lot of folks didn't think I could win including
column5: by the way
column6: my mother. (LAUGHTER) I said I'd do four things; tort reform
column7: education reform
column8: welfare reform and juvenile justice reform. And I won. And I had the will of the people in my state behind me. And then I brought folks together to get it done. And that's what we need
column9: I think
column10: in this election. To me that's what it's all about. I'm sure your 6th grade kids are listening and saying
column11: these guys will say anything to get elected. But there's a record
column12: and that's what I hope people look at. One of my promises is going to be Social Security reform
column13: and you bet
column14: we need to take a trillion dollars out of that $2.4 trillion surplus. Now remember
column15: Social Security revenue exceeds expenses up until 2015. People are going to get paid. But if you're a younger worker
column16: if you're younger
column17: you better hope this country thinks differently
column18: otherwise you're gonna be faced with huge payroll taxes or reduced benefits. And you bet we're gonna take a trillion dollars of your own money and let you invest it under safe guidelines so you get a better rate of return on the money than the paltry 2% that the federal government gets for you today. That's one of my promises. But it's gonna require people to bring both Republicans and Democrats together to get it done. That's what it requires. There was a chance to get this done. It was a bipartisan approach
column19: but it's been rejected. I'm going to bring them together.

column1: Well
column2: first of all
column3: Jim
column4: I would like to respond to what the governor just said. Because the trillion dollars that has been promised to young people has also been promised to older people. And you cannot keep both promises. If you're in your mid-40's under the governor's plan
column5: Social Security will be bankrupt by the time you retire
column6: if he takes it out of the Social Security Trust Fund. Under my plan it will be -- its solvency will be extended until you're 100. Now that is the difference. And the governor may not want to answer that question
column7: he may want to call it a high school debating trick
column8: but let me tell you this. This election is not about debating tricks
column9: it is about your future. The reason Social Security -- he says it gets 2%. You know
column10: it's not a bank account that just pays back money that's invested. It is also used to give your mothers and fathers the Social Security checks that they live on. If you take a trillion dollars out of that Social Security Trust Fund
column11: how are the checks going to be -- how are you going to keep faith with the seniors? Now let me come directly to your question.

column1: Well
column2: can I answer that? One reason people are skeptical is because people don't answer the questions they've been asked. The trillion dollars comes out of the surplus so that you can invest some of your own money. There's just a difference of opinion. I want workers to have their own assets. It's who you trust
column3: government or people.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 15)	" Yes. (LAUGHTER) I am a person who keeps promises. And
column4: you know
column5: we've heard a lot about -- from the governor about not much being done in the last eight years
column6: as if the promises that I made eight years ago have not been kept. I think the record shows otherwise. We have gone from the biggest deficits eight years ago to the biggest surpluses in history today. Instead of high unemployment
column7: we now have the lowest African-American unemployment
column8: the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured. 22 million new jobs
column9: very low unemployment nationally. Instead of ballooning the debt and multiplying it four times over
column10: we have seen the debt actually begun to be paid down. Here are some promises that I'll make to you now. I will balance the budget every year. I will pay down the debt every year. I will give middle-class Americans tax cuts
column11: meaningful ones. And I will invest in education
column12: health care
column13: protecting the environment and retirement security. We both made promises in this campaign. I promise you I will keep mine. Let me tell you about one of the governor's. He has promised a trillion dollars out of the Social Security Trust Fund for young working adults to invest and save on their own. But he's promised seniors that their Social Security benefits will not be cut
column14: and he's promised the same trillion dollars to them. So this is a show me state. Reminds me of the line from the movie
column15: ""Show me the money."" Which one of those promises will you keep and which will you break
column16: Governor?

column1: Thank you for your question. (LAUGHTER) I -- there's an old high school debating trick
column2: which is to answer something and then attack your opponent at the end. You asked about promises. You were promised that Medicare would be reformed
column3: and that Social Security would be reformed. You were promised a middle-class tax cut in 1992. It didn't happen. There's too much bitterness in Washington. There's too much wrangling. It's time to have a fresh start. One of the reasons I was successful as the governor of Texas is because I didn't try to be all things to all people. When I campaigned in a race
column4: a lot of folks didn't think I could win including
column5: by the way
column6: my mother. (LAUGHTER) I said I'd do four things; tort reform
column7: education reform
column8: welfare reform and juvenile justice reform. And I won. And I had the will of the people in my state behind me. And then I brought folks together to get it done. And that's what we need
column9: I think
column10: in this election. To me that's what it's all about. I'm sure your 6th grade kids are listening and saying
column11: these guys will say anything to get elected. But there's a record
column12: and that's what I hope people look at. One of my promises is going to be Social Security reform
column13: and you bet
column14: we need to take a trillion dollars out of that $2.4 trillion surplus. Now remember
column15: Social Security revenue exceeds expenses up until 2015. People are going to get paid. But if you're a younger worker
column16: if you're younger
column17: you better hope this country thinks differently
column18: otherwise you're gonna be faced with huge payroll taxes or reduced benefits. And you bet we're gonna take a trillion dollars of your own money and let you invest it under safe guidelines so you get a better rate of return on the money than the paltry 2% that the federal government gets for you today. That's one of my promises. But it's gonna require people to bring both Republicans and Democrats together to get it done. That's what it requires. There was a chance to get this done. It was a bipartisan approach
column19: but it's been rejected. I'm going to bring them together.

column1: Well
column2: first of all
column3: Jim
column4: I would like to respond to what the governor just said. Because the trillion dollars that has been promised to young people has also been promised to older people. And you cannot keep both promises. If you're in your mid-40's under the governor's plan
column5: Social Security will be bankrupt by the time you retire
column6: if he takes it out of the Social Security Trust Fund. Under my plan it will be -- its solvency will be extended until you're 100. Now that is the difference. And the governor may not want to answer that question
column7: he may want to call it a high school debating trick
column8: but let me tell you this. This election is not about debating tricks
column9: it is about your future. The reason Social Security -- he says it gets 2%. You know
column10: it's not a bank account that just pays back money that's invested. It is also used to give your mothers and fathers the Social Security checks that they live on. If you take a trillion dollars out of that Social Security Trust Fund
column11: how are the checks going to be -- how are you going to keep faith with the seniors? Now let me come directly to your question.

column1: Well
column2: can I answer that? One reason people are skeptical is because people don't answer the questions they've been asked. The trillion dollars comes out of the surplus so that you can invest some of your own money. There's just a difference of opinion. I want workers to have their own assets. It's who you trust
column3: government or people.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 16)	" Thank you very much
column4: Jim
column5: and I'll begin by answering your questions -- your last question. I believe that a lot of people are skeptical about people in politics today because we have seen a time of great challenge for our country. Since the assassination of our best leaders in the '60's
column6: since the Vietnam War
column7: since Watergate
column8: and because we need campaign finance reform. I would like to tell you something about me. I keep my word. I have kept the faith. I've kept the faith with my country. I volunteered for the Army. I served in Vietnam. I kept the faith with my family. Tipper and I have been married for 30 years. We have devoted ourselves to our children and now our nearly one-and-a-half-year-old grandson. I have kept the faith with our country. Nine times I have raised my hand to take an oath to the Constitution
column9: and I have never violated that oath. I have not spent the last quarter century in pursuit of personal wealth. I have spent the last quarter century fighting for middle-class working men and women in the United States of America. I believe very deeply that you have to be willing to stand up and fight no matter what powerful forces might be on the other side. If you want somebody who is willing to fight for you
column10: I am asking for your support and your vote and
column11: yes
column12: your confidence and your willingness to believe that we can do the right thing in America
column13: and be the better for it. We've made some progress during the last eight years. We have seen the strongest economy in the history of the United States. Lower crime rates for eight years in a row. Highest private home ownership ever
column14: but I'll make you one promise here. You ain't seen nothing yet. And I will keep that promise.

column1: Well
column2: Jim
column3: I want to thank you and thank the folks here at Washington University and the vice president. Appreciate the chance to have a good
column4: honest dialogue about our differences of opinion. I think after three debates the good people of this country understand there is a difference of opinion. There is a difference between big federal government and somebody who is coming from outside of Washington who will trust individuals. I've got an agenda that I want to get done for the country. It's an agenda that says we're going to reform Medicare to make sure seniors have got prescription drugs and to give seniors different options from which they can choose. It's an agenda that says we're listen to the young voices in Social Security and say we're going to think differently about making sure we have a system
column5: but also fulfill the promise to the seniors in America. A promise made will be a promise kept should I be fortunate enough to become your president. I want to have the military keeping the peace. I want to make sure the public school system in America keeps its promise so not one child is left behind. After setting priorities
column6: I want to give some of your money back. I don't think the surplus is the government's money. I think it's the people's money. I don't think the surplus exists because of the ingenuity and hard work of the federal government
column7: I think it exists because of the ingenuity and hard work of the American people. And you ought to have some of this surplus so you can save and dream and build. I look forward to the final weeks of this campaign. I'm asking for your vote. For those of you for me
column8: thanks for your help. For those of you for my opponent
column9: please only vote once. (LAUGHTER) But for those who have not made up their mind
column10: I would like to conclude by this promise. Should I be fortunate enough to become your president
column11: when I put my hand on the Bible
column12: I will swear to not only uphold the laws of the land
column13: but I will also swear to uphold the honor and the dignity of the office to which I have been elected
column14: so help me God. Thank you very much.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 2)	" Well
column4: that's a great question. I think one of the problems we have
column5: particularly for seniors
column6: is there is no prescription drug coverage in Medicare. And therefore
column7: when they have to try to purchase drugs they do so on their own
column8: there's no kind of collective bargaining
column9: no power of purchasing among seniors. So I think step one to make sure prescription drugs is more affordable for seniors
column10: and those are the folks who really rely upon prescription drugs a lot these days
column11: is to reform the Medicare system
column12: is to have prescription drugs as an integral part of Medicare once and for all. The problem we have today is like the patient's bill of rights
column13: particularly with health care
column14: there's a lot of bickering in Washington
column15: D.C. It's kind of like a political issue as opposed to a people issue. So what I want to do is I want to call upon Republicans and Democrats to forget all the arguing and finger pointing
column16: and come together and take care of our seniors' prescription drug program
column17: that says we'll pay for the poor seniors
column18: we'll help all seniors with prescription drugs. In the meantime
column19: I think it's important to have what's called Immediate Helping Hand
column20: which is direct money to states so that seniors
column22: don't have to choose between food and medicine. That's part of an overall overhaul. The purchasing powers. And I'm against price controls. I think price controls would hurt our ability to continue important research and development. Drug therapies are replacing a lot of medicines as we used to know it. One of the most important things is to continue the research and development component. And so I'm against price controls. Expediting drugs through the FDA makes sense
column23: of course. Allowing the new bill that was passed in the Congress made sense to allow for
column24: you know
column25: drugs that were sold overseas to come back and other countries to come back into the United States. That makes sense. But the best thing to do is to reform Medicare.

column1: All right
column2: here we go again. Now look
column3: if you want someone who will spend a lot of words describing a whole convoluted process and then end up supporting legislation that is supported by the big drug companies
column4: this is your man. If you want someone who will fight for you and who will fight for the middle-class families and working men and women
column5: who are sick and tired of having their parents and grandparents pay higher prices for prescription drugs than anybody else
column6: then I want to fight for you. And you asked a great question because it's not only seniors. Listen
column7: for 24 years I have never been afraid to take on the big drug companies. They do some great things. They discover great new cures and that's great. We want them to continue that. But they are now spending more money on advertising and promotion. You see all these ads? Than they are on research and development. And they are trying artificially extend the monopoly patent protection so they can keep charging these very high prices. I want to streamline the approval of the competing generic drugs and the new kinds of treatments that can compete with them so we bring the price down for everybody. Now
column8: briefly
column9: let me tell you how my prescription drug plan works. The governor talked about Medicare. I propose a real prescription drug benefit under Medicare for all seniors
column10: all seniors
column11: and here's how it works. You pick your own doctor
column12: and nobody can take that away from you. The doctor chooses the prescription that you need and nobody can overrule your doctor. You go to your own pharmacy and then Medicare pays half the price. If you're poor
column13: they pay all of it. If you have extraordinarily high cost
column14: then they pay all over $4
column15: 000 out-of-pocket. And I'll bring new competition to bring the price down. And if you pass the big drug companies' bill
column16: nothing will happen.

column4: you know
column5: it's hard to make people love one another. I wish I knew the law because I would darn sure sign it. I wish I knew the law that said all of us would be good parents. One of the things the next president must do is to remind people that if we are going to have a responsible period in America
column6: that each of us must love our children with all our heart and all our soul. I happened to believe strong accountability encourages parental involvement
column7: though. I think when you measure and post results on the Internet or in the town newspapers
column8: most parents say wait a minute
column9: my child's school isn't doing what I want it to do and
column10: therefore
column11: become involved in education. I recognize there are some who just don't seem to care. But there are a lot of parents who feel like everything is going well in their child's school
column12: and all of a sudden they wake up and realize that wait a minute
column13: standards aren't being met. That's why I'm so strong for accountability. I believe we ought to measure a lot
column14: three
column15: four
column16: five
column17: six
column18: seven
column19: eighth grade. We do so in my state of Texas. One of the good things we've gone in Texas is we have strong accountability because you can't cure unless you know. You can't solve a problem unless you diagnose it. I strongly believe that one of the best things to encourage parental involvement also is to know that the classrooms will be safe and secure. That's why I support a teacher liability act at the federal level
column20: that says if a teacher or principal upholds reasonable standards of classroom discipline they can't be sued. They can't be sued. I think parents will be more involved with education when they know their children's classrooms are safe and secure as well. I also believe that we need to say to people that if you cannot meet standards
column21: there has to be a consequence. Instead of just comes the soft bigotry of low expectations
column22: that there has to be a consequence. We can't continue to shuffle children through school. And one of the consequences to allow parents to have different choices.

column1: We have huge difference between us on this question. I'd like to start by telling you what my vision is. I see a day in the United States of America where all of our public schools are considered excellent
column2: world class. Where there are no failing schools
column3: where the classrooms are small enough in size
column4: number of students
column5: so that the teacher can spend enough one-on-one time with each student. Now that means recruiting new teachers for the public schools. It means in my plan hiring bonuses to get 100
column6: 000 new teachers in the public schools within the next four years. It means also helping local school districts that sometimes find the parents of school age children outvoted on bond issues
column7: to give them some help with interest-free bonding authority so that we can build new schools and modernize the classrooms. We need to give teachers the training and professional development that they need
column8: including a paid time off to go visit the classroom of a master teacher to pick up some new skills. I want to give every middle-class family a $10
column9: 000 a year tax deduction for college tuition so that middle-class families will always be able to send their kids on to college. I want to work for universal free school because we know from all the studies that the youngsters learn
column10: kids learn more in the first few years of life than any where else. Now
column11: I said there was a contrast. Governor Bush is for vouchers
column12: and in his plan he proposes to drain more money
column13: more taxpayer money out of the public schools for private school vouchers than all of the money that he proposes in his entire budget for public schools themselves. And only one in 20 students would be eligible for these vouchers
column14: and they wouldn't even pay the full tuition to private school. I think that's a mistake. I don't think we should give up on the private schools and leave kids trapped in failing schools. I think we -- I think we should make it the number one priority to make our schools the best in the world
column15: all of them.

column1: Yeah
column2: I appreciate that. I think any time we end with one of these attacks
column3: it's appropriate to respond. Here's what I think. First of all
column4: vouchers are up to states. If you want to do a voucher program in Missouri
column5: fine. I strongly believe in local control of schools. I'm a governor of state and I don't like it when the federal government tells us what to do. I believe in local control of schools. But here's what I said. I've said to the extent we spend federal money on disadvantaged children
column6: we want the schools to show us whether or not the children are learning. What's unreasonable about that? We expect there to be standards met and we expect there to be measurement. And if we find success we'll praise it. But when we find children trapped in schools that will not change and will not teach

column12: the status quo is fine

column3: Governor Bush
column4: states would be required to pay vouchers to students to match the vouchers so that the federal government would put up. Now
column5: you're -- and the way it would happen is that under his plan
column6: if a school was designated as failing
column7: the kids would be trapped there for another three years and then some of them would get federal vouchers and the state would be forced to match those
column8: that money. Under my plan
column9: if a school is failing
column10: we work with the states to give them the authority and the resources to close down that school and reopen it right away with a new principal
column11: a new faculty
column12: a turn-around team of specialists who know what they're doing. It's based on the plan of Governor Jim Hunt in North Carolina
column13: and it works great.

column1: If I thought that there was no alternative
column2: then I might feel differently. But I have an obligation to fight to make sure there are no failing schools. We have to turn around -- most schools are excellent
column3: but we have to make sure that all of them are.

column1: We have huge difference between us on this question. I'd like to start by telling you what my vision is. I see a day in the United States of America where all of our public schools are considered excellent
column2: world class. Where there are no failing schools
column3: where the classrooms are small enough in size
column4: number of students
column5: so that the teacher can spend enough one-on-one time with each student. Now that means recruiting new teachers for the public schools. It means in my plan hiring bonuses to get 100
column6: 000 new teachers in the public schools within the next four years. It means also helping local school districts that sometimes find the parents of school age children outvoted on bond issues
column7: to give them some help with interest-free bonding authority so that we can build new schools and modernize the classrooms. We need to give teachers the training and professional development that they need
column8: including a paid time off to go visit the classroom of a master teacher to pick up some new skills. I want to give every middle-class family a $10
column9: 000 a year tax deduction for college tuition so that middle-class families will always be able to send their kids on to college. I want to work for universal free school because we know from all the studies that the youngsters learn
column10: kids learn more in the first few years of life than any where else. Now
column11: I said there was a contrast. Governor Bush is for vouchers
column12: and in his plan he proposes to drain more money
column13: more taxpayer money out of the public schools for private school vouchers than all of the money that he proposes in his entire budget for public schools themselves. And only one in 20 students would be eligible for these vouchers
column14: and they wouldn't even pay the full tuition to private school. I think that's a mistake. I don't think we should give up on the private schools and leave kids trapped in failing schools. I think we -- I think we should make it the number one priority to make our schools the best in the world
column15: all of them.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 5)	" What grade do you teach?

column1: High school. I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues. Traditionally
column2: if you've been involved in a campaign like that
column3: you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote. It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population
column4: but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever. More than 90% of America's children go to public schools. And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running. We've got to do something about this. And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts. They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it. Look
column5: we're in an information age. Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college. And again
column6: I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also
column7: and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning
column8: but it all starts with the public school teachers. My proposal gives $10
column9: 000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed. Now
column10: accountability
column11: we basically agree on accountability. My plan requires testing of all students. It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't. It requires testing of all new teachers
column12: including in the subjects that they teach. We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are
column13: and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.

column1: When you total up all the federal spending he wants to do
column2: it's the largest increase in federal spending in years. And there's just not going to be enough money. I have been a governor of a big state
column3: I have made education my number one priority. That's what governors ought to do. They ought to say this is the most important thing we do as a state. The federal government puts about 6% of the money up. They put about
column4: you know
column5: 60% of the strings where you have to fill out the paperwork. I don't know if you have to be a paperwork filler-outer
column6: but most of it's because of the federal government. What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money. One size does not fit all. I worry about federalizing education if I were you. I believe strongly that the federal government can help
column7: we need to fund Headstart. We need to have accountability. The Vice President's plan does not have annual accountability
column8: third grade
column9: fourth grade
column10: fifth grade. We need to demand on results. I believe strongly in a teacher protection act like I mentioned. I hear from teachers all the time about the lawsuits and the threats
column11: respect in the classroom. Part of it's because you can't -- you can't control the classroom. You can't have a consequence for somebody without fear of getting sued under federal law. So I'm going to ask the Congress to pass a teacher protection act. So I believe in flexibility
column12: I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing
column13: curriculum that works
column14: phonics works
column15: by the way
column16: it needs to be a part of our curriculum. There needs to be flexibility for teacher training and teacher hiring with federal money. The federal government can be a part
column17: but don't fall prey to all this stuff about money here and money there because education is really funded at the local level. 94% comes from the local level.

column1: Absolutely not. Absolutely not. I'm so glad that I have the chance to knock that down. Look
column2: the problem is that under Governor Bush's plan
column3: $1.6 trillion tax cut
column4: mostly to the wealthy
column5: under his own budget numbers
column6: he proposes spending more money for a tax cut just for the wealthiest 1% than all the new money he budgets for education
column7: health care and national defense combined. Now under my plan we'll balance the budget every year. I'm not just saying this. I'm not just talking. I have helped to balance the budget for the first time in 30 years
column8: paid down the debt. And under my plan
column9: in four years
column10: as the percentage of our gross domestic product
column11: federal spending will be the smallest that it has been in 50 years. One reason is
column12: you know
column13: the third biggest spending item in our budget is interest on the national debt? We get nothing for it. We keep the good faith and credit of the United States. I will pay down the debt every single year until it is eliminated early in the next decade. That gets rid of the third biggest intrusion of the federal government in our economy. Now
column14: because the governor has all this money for a tax cut mostly to the wealthy
column15: there is no money left over
column16: so schools get testing and lawsuit reform and not much else.

column1: Well
column2: he's wrong. (LAUGHTER) Just add up all the numbers. It's three times bigger than what President Clinton proposed. The Senate Budget Committee --

column1: That was in an ad
column2: Jim
column3: that was knocked down by the journalists who analyzed the ad and said it was misleading.

column1: My turn?
Forget the journalists. He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. This is a big spender. And he ought to be proud of it
column2: it's part of his record. We just have a different philosophy. Let me talk about tax relief. If you pay taxes
column3: you ought to get tax relief. The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I don't think that's the role of the president to pick you're right and you're not right. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody ought to get it. And therefore
column5: wealthy people are going to get it. But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits. And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes. If you're a family of four making $50
column6: 000 in Missouri
column7: you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes. What I've done is set priorities and funded them. And there's extra money. And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back. It's a difference of opinion. He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money. I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people. It's just the right position to take.

column1: Can we take the time --
Of course it does. If you pay taxes
column2: you are going to get a benefit. People who pay taxes will get tax relief.

column1: Let me finish. Under my plan
column2: if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today. Afterwards they pay 64%. This is a fair plan. You know why? Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother making $22
column3: 000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children
column4: for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200
column6: and that's not right. So I want to do something about that.

column1: Yeah
column2: look. Look
column3: this isn't about Governor Bush

column1: High school. I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues. Traditionally
column2: if you've been involved in a campaign like that
column3: you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote. It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population
column4: but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever. More than 90% of America's children go to public schools. And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running. We've got to do something about this. And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts. They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it. Look
column5: we're in an information age. Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college. And again
column6: I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also
column7: and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning
column8: but it all starts with the public school teachers. My proposal gives $10
column9: 000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed. Now
column10: accountability
column11: we basically agree on accountability. My plan requires testing of all students. It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't. It requires testing of all new teachers
column12: including in the subjects that they teach. We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are
column13: and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.

column6: but most of it's because of the federal government. What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money. One size does not fit all. I worry about federalizing education if I were you. I believe strongly that the federal government can help

column12: I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing

column1: My turn?
Forget the journalists. He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. This is a big spender. And he ought to be proud of it
column2: it's part of his record. We just have a different philosophy. Let me talk about tax relief. If you pay taxes
column3: you ought to get tax relief. The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I don't think that's the role of the president to pick you're right and you're not right. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody ought to get it. And therefore
column5: wealthy people are going to get it. But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits. And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes. If you're a family of four making $50
column6: 000 in Missouri
column7: you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes. What I've done is set priorities and funded them. And there's extra money. And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back. It's a difference of opinion. He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money. I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people. It's just the right position to take.

column1: Can we take the time --
Of course it does. If you pay taxes
column2: you are going to get a benefit. People who pay taxes will get tax relief.

column1: Let me finish. Under my plan
column2: if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today. Afterwards they pay 64%. This is a fair plan. You know why? Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother making $22
column3: 000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children
column4: for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200
column6: and that's not right. So I want to do something about that.

column1: Yeah
column2: look. Look
column3: this isn't about Governor Bush
column4: it's not about me. It is about you. And I want to come back to something I said before. If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then
column5: emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy
column6: here is your man. If you want somebody who will fight for you and who will fight to have middle-class tax cuts
column7: then I am your man. I want to be. Now
column8: I doubt anybody here makes more than $330
column9: 000 a year. I won't ask you
column10: but if you do
column11: you're in the top 1%.

column1: I'm not going to ask them. But if everyone here in this audience was dead on in the middle of the middle-class
column2: then the tax cuts for every single one of you all added up would be less than the tax cut his plan would give to just one member of that top wealthiest 1%. Now you judge for yourselves whether or not that's fair.

column1: Good. 50 million Americans get no tax relief under his plan.
That's not right.
You may not be one of them
column2: you're just not one of the right people. And secondly
column3: we've had enough fighting. It's time to unite. You talk about eight years? In eight years they haven't gotten anything done on Medicare
column4: on Social Security
column5: a patient's bill of rights. It's time to get something done.

column1: Hey
column2: I've got to answer that
column3: Jim.

column1: Medicare -- I cast the tie-breaking vote to add 26 years to the life of Medicare. It was due to go bankrupt in 1999 and that 50 million figure again
column2: the newspapers -- I said -- you said forget the journalists
column3: but they are the keepers of the score card and whether or not you're using facts that aren't right. And that fact is just not right.

column1: High school. I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues. Traditionally
column2: if you've been involved in a campaign like that
column3: you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote. It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population
column4: but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever. More than 90% of America's children go to public schools. And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running. We've got to do something about this. And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts. They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it. Look
column5: we're in an information age. Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college. And again
column6: I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also
column7: and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning
column8: but it all starts with the public school teachers. My proposal gives $10
column9: 000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed. Now
column10: accountability
column11: we basically agree on accountability. My plan requires testing of all students. It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't. It requires testing of all new teachers
column12: including in the subjects that they teach. We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are
column13: and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.

column4: you know

column6: but most of it's because of the federal government. What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money. One size does not fit all. I worry about federalizing education if I were you. I believe strongly that the federal government can help

column9: fourth grade

column12: I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing
column13: curriculum that works
column14: phonics works
column15: by the way
column16: it needs to be a part of our curriculum. There needs to be flexibility for teacher training and teacher hiring with federal money. The federal government can be a part
column17: but don't fall prey to all this stuff about money here and money there because education is really funded at the local level. 94% comes from the local level.

column1: Absolutely not. Absolutely not. I'm so glad that I have the chance to knock that down. Look
column2: the problem is that under Governor Bush's plan
column3: $1.6 trillion tax cut
column4: mostly to the wealthy
column5: under his own budget numbers
column6: he proposes spending more money for a tax cut just for the wealthiest 1% than all the new money he budgets for education
column7: health care and national defense combined. Now under my plan we'll balance the budget every year. I'm not just saying this. I'm not just talking. I have helped to balance the budget for the first time in 30 years
column8: paid down the debt. And under my plan
column9: in four years
column10: as the percentage of our gross domestic product
column11: federal spending will be the smallest that it has been in 50 years. One reason is
column12: you know
column13: the third biggest spending item in our budget is interest on the national debt? We get nothing for it. We keep the good faith and credit of the United States. I will pay down the debt every single year until it is eliminated early in the next decade. That gets rid of the third biggest intrusion of the federal government in our economy. Now
column14: because the governor has all this money for a tax cut mostly to the wealthy
column15: there is no money left over
column16: so schools get testing and lawsuit reform and not much else.

column1: Well
column2: he's wrong. (LAUGHTER) Just add up all the numbers. It's three times bigger than what President Clinton proposed. The Senate Budget Committee --

column1: That was in an ad
column2: Jim
column3: that was knocked down by the journalists who analyzed the ad and said it was misleading.

column1: My turn?
Forget the journalists. He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. This is a big spender. And he ought to be proud of it
column2: it's part of his record. We just have a different philosophy. Let me talk about tax relief. If you pay taxes
column3: you ought to get tax relief. The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I don't think that's the role of the president to pick you're right and you're not right. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody ought to get it. And therefore
column5: wealthy people are going to get it. But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits. And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes. If you're a family of four making $50
column6: 000 in Missouri
column7: you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes. What I've done is set priorities and funded them. And there's extra money. And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back. It's a difference of opinion. He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money. I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people. It's just the right position to take.

column1: Can we take the time --
Of course it does. If you pay taxes
column2: you are going to get a benefit. People who pay taxes will get tax relief.

column1: Let me finish. Under my plan
column2: if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today. Afterwards they pay 64%. This is a fair plan. You know why? Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother making $22
column3: 000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children
column4: for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200
column6: and that's not right. So I want to do something about that.

column1: Yeah
column2: look. Look
column3: this isn't about Governor Bush
column4: it's not about me. It is about you. And I want to come back to something I said before. If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then
column5: emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy
column6: here is your man. If you want somebody who will fight for you and who will fight to have middle-class tax cuts
column7: then I am your man. I want to be. Now
column8: I doubt anybody here makes more than $330
column9: 000 a year. I won't ask you
column10: but if you do
column11: you're in the top 1%.

column1: I'm not going to ask them. But if everyone here in this audience was dead on in the middle of the middle-class
column2: then the tax cuts for every single one of you all added up would be less than the tax cut his plan would give to just one member of that top wealthiest 1%. Now you judge for yourselves whether or not that's fair.

column1: Good. 50 million Americans get no tax relief under his plan.
That's not right.
You may not be one of them
column2: you're just not one of the right people. And secondly
column3: we've had enough fighting. It's time to unite. You talk about eight years? In eight years they haven't gotten anything done on Medicare
column4: on Social Security
column5: a patient's bill of rights. It's time to get something done.

column1: Hey
column2: I've got to answer that
column3: Jim.

column1: Medicare -- I cast the tie-breaking vote to add 26 years to the life of Medicare. It was due to go bankrupt in 1999 and that 50 million figure again
column2: the newspapers -- I said -- you said forget the journalists
column3: but they are the keepers of the score card and whether or not you're using facts that aren't right. And that fact is just not right.

column3: 5)	" What grade do you teach?

column1: High school. I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues. Traditionally
column2: if you've been involved in a campaign like that
column3: you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote. It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population
column4: but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever. More than 90% of America's children go to public schools. And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running. We've got to do something about this. And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts. They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it. Look
column5: we're in an information age. Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college. And again
column6: I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also
column7: and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning
column8: but it all starts with the public school teachers. My proposal gives $10
column9: 000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed. Now
column10: accountability
column11: we basically agree on accountability. My plan requires testing of all students. It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't. It requires testing of all new teachers
column12: including in the subjects that they teach. We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are
column13: and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.

column1: When you total up all the federal spending he wants to do
column2: it's the largest increase in federal spending in years. And there's just not going to be enough money. I have been a governor of a big state
column3: I have made education my number one priority. That's what governors ought to do. They ought to say this is the most important thing we do as a state. The federal government puts about 6% of the money up. They put about
column4: you know
column5: 60% of the strings where you have to fill out the paperwork. I don't know if you have to be a paperwork filler-outer
column6: but most of it's because of the federal government. What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money. One size does not fit all. I worry about federalizing education if I were you. I believe strongly that the federal government can help
column7: we need to fund Headstart. We need to have accountability. The Vice President's plan does not have annual accountability
column8: third grade
column9: fourth grade
column10: fifth grade. We need to demand on results. I believe strongly in a teacher protection act like I mentioned. I hear from teachers all the time about the lawsuits and the threats
column11: respect in the classroom. Part of it's because you can't -- you can't control the classroom. You can't have a consequence for somebody without fear of getting sued under federal law. So I'm going to ask the Congress to pass a teacher protection act. So I believe in flexibility
column12: I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing
column13: curriculum that works
column14: phonics works
column15: by the way
column16: it needs to be a part of our curriculum. There needs to be flexibility for teacher training and teacher hiring with federal money. The federal government can be a part
column17: but don't fall prey to all this stuff about money here and money there because education is really funded at the local level. 94% comes from the local level.

column1: Absolutely not. Absolutely not. I'm so glad that I have the chance to knock that down. Look
column2: the problem is that under Governor Bush's plan
column3: $1.6 trillion tax cut
column4: mostly to the wealthy
column5: under his own budget numbers
column6: he proposes spending more money for a tax cut just for the wealthiest 1% than all the new money he budgets for education
column7: health care and national defense combined. Now under my plan we'll balance the budget every year. I'm not just saying this. I'm not just talking. I have helped to balance the budget for the first time in 30 years
column8: paid down the debt. And under my plan
column9: in four years
column10: as the percentage of our gross domestic product
column11: federal spending will be the smallest that it has been in 50 years. One reason is
column12: you know
column13: the third biggest spending item in our budget is interest on the national debt? We get nothing for it. We keep the good faith and credit of the United States. I will pay down the debt every single year until it is eliminated early in the next decade. That gets rid of the third biggest intrusion of the federal government in our economy. Now
column14: because the governor has all this money for a tax cut mostly to the wealthy
column15: there is no money left over
column16: so schools get testing and lawsuit reform and not much else.

column1: Well
column2: he's wrong. (LAUGHTER) Just add up all the numbers. It's three times bigger than what President Clinton proposed. The Senate Budget Committee --

column1: That was in an ad
column2: Jim
column3: that was knocked down by the journalists who analyzed the ad and said it was misleading.

column1: My turn?
Forget the journalists. He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. This is a big spender. And he ought to be proud of it
column2: it's part of his record. We just have a different philosophy. Let me talk about tax relief. If you pay taxes
column3: you ought to get tax relief. The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I don't think that's the role of the president to pick you're right and you're not right. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody ought to get it. And therefore
column5: wealthy people are going to get it. But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits. And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes. If you're a family of four making $50
column6: 000 in Missouri
column7: you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes. What I've done is set priorities and funded them. And there's extra money. And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back. It's a difference of opinion. He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money. I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people. It's just the right position to take.

column1: Can we take the time --
Of course it does. If you pay taxes
column2: you are going to get a benefit. People who pay taxes will get tax relief.

column1: Let me finish. Under my plan
column2: if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today. Afterwards they pay 64%. This is a fair plan. You know why? Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother making $22
column3: 000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children
column4: for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200
column6: and that's not right. So I want to do something about that.

column1: Yeah
column2: look. Look
column3: this isn't about Governor Bush
column4: it's not about me. It is about you. And I want to come back to something I said before. If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then
column5: emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy
column6: here is your man. If you want somebody who will fight for you and who will fight to have middle-class tax cuts
column7: then I am your man. I want to be. Now
column8: I doubt anybody here makes more than $330
column9: 000 a year. I won't ask you
column10: but if you do
column11: you're in the top 1%.

column1: I'm not going to ask them. But if everyone here in this audience was dead on in the middle of the middle-class
column2: then the tax cuts for every single one of you all added up would be less than the tax cut his plan would give to just one member of that top wealthiest 1%. Now you judge for yourselves whether or not that's fair.

column1: Good. 50 million Americans get no tax relief under his plan.
That's not right.
You may not be one of them
column2: you're just not one of the right people. And secondly
column3: we've had enough fighting. It's time to unite. You talk about eight years? In eight years they haven't gotten anything done on Medicare
column4: on Social Security
column5: a patient's bill of rights. It's time to get something done.

column1: Hey
column2: I've got to answer that
column3: Jim.

column1: Medicare -- I cast the tie-breaking vote to add 26 years to the life of Medicare. It was due to go bankrupt in 1999 and that 50 million figure again
column2: the newspapers -- I said -- you said forget the journalists
column3: but they are the keepers of the score card and whether or not you're using facts that aren't right. And that fact is just not right.
