column1: High school. I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues. Traditionally
column2: if you've been involved in a campaign like that
column3: you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote. It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population
column4: but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever. More than 90% of America's children go to public schools. And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running. We've got to do something about this. And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts. They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it. Look
column5: we're in an information age. Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college. And again
column6: I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also
column7: and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning
column8: but it all starts with the public school teachers. My proposal gives $10
column9: 000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed. Now
column10: accountability
column11: we basically agree on accountability. My plan requires testing of all students. It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't. It requires testing of all new teachers
column12: including in the subjects that they teach. We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are
column13: and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.

column1: When you total up all the federal spending he wants to do
column2: it's the largest increase in federal spending in years. And there's just not going to be enough money. I have been a governor of a big state
column3: I have made education my number one priority. That's what governors ought to do. They ought to say this is the most important thing we do as a state. The federal government puts about 6% of the money up. They put about
column4: you know
column5: 60% of the strings where you have to fill out the paperwork. I don't know if you have to be a paperwork filler-outer
column6: but most of it's because of the federal government. What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money. One size does not fit all. I worry about federalizing education if I were you. I believe strongly that the federal government can help
column7: we need to fund Headstart. We need to have accountability. The Vice President's plan does not have annual accountability
column8: third grade
column9: fourth grade
column10: fifth grade. We need to demand on results. I believe strongly in a teacher protection act like I mentioned. I hear from teachers all the time about the lawsuits and the threats
column11: respect in the classroom. Part of it's because you can't -- you can't control the classroom. You can't have a consequence for somebody without fear of getting sued under federal law. So I'm going to ask the Congress to pass a teacher protection act. So I believe in flexibility
column12: I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing
column13: curriculum that works
column14: phonics works
column15: by the way
column16: it needs to be a part of our curriculum. There needs to be flexibility for teacher training and teacher hiring with federal money. The federal government can be a part
column17: but don't fall prey to all this stuff about money here and money there because education is really funded at the local level. 94% comes from the local level.

column1: Absolutely not. Absolutely not. I'm so glad that I have the chance to knock that down. Look
column2: the problem is that under Governor Bush's plan
column3: $1.6 trillion tax cut
column4: mostly to the wealthy
column5: under his own budget numbers
column6: he proposes spending more money for a tax cut just for the wealthiest 1% than all the new money he budgets for education
column7: health care and national defense combined. Now under my plan we'll balance the budget every year. I'm not just saying this. I'm not just talking. I have helped to balance the budget for the first time in 30 years
column8: paid down the debt. And under my plan
column9: in four years
column10: as the percentage of our gross domestic product
column11: federal spending will be the smallest that it has been in 50 years. One reason is
column12: you know
column13: the third biggest spending item in our budget is interest on the national debt? We get nothing for it. We keep the good faith and credit of the United States. I will pay down the debt every single year until it is eliminated early in the next decade. That gets rid of the third biggest intrusion of the federal government in our economy. Now
column14: because the governor has all this money for a tax cut mostly to the wealthy
column15: there is no money left over
column16: so schools get testing and lawsuit reform and not much else.

column1: Well
column2: he's wrong. (LAUGHTER) Just add up all the numbers. It's three times bigger than what President Clinton proposed. The Senate Budget Committee --

column1: That was in an ad
column2: Jim
column3: that was knocked down by the journalists who analyzed the ad and said it was misleading.

column1: My turn?
Forget the journalists. He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. This is a big spender. And he ought to be proud of it
column2: it's part of his record. We just have a different philosophy. Let me talk about tax relief. If you pay taxes
column3: you ought to get tax relief. The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I don't think that's the role of the president to pick you're right and you're not right. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody ought to get it. And therefore
column5: wealthy people are going to get it. But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits. And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes. If you're a family of four making $50
column6: 000 in Missouri
column7: you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes. What I've done is set priorities and funded them. And there's extra money. And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back. It's a difference of opinion. He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money. I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people. It's just the right position to take.

column1: Can we take the time --
Of course it does. If you pay taxes
column2: you are going to get a benefit. People who pay taxes will get tax relief.

column1: Let me finish. Under my plan
column2: if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today. Afterwards they pay 64%. This is a fair plan. You know why? Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother making $22
column3: 000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children
column4: for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200
column6: and that's not right. So I want to do something about that.

column1: Yeah
column2: look. Look
column3: this isn't about Governor Bush
column4: it's not about me. It is about you. And I want to come back to something I said before. If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then
column5: emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy
column6: here is your man. If you want somebody who will fight for you and who will fight to have middle-class tax cuts
column7: then I am your man. I want to be. Now
column8: I doubt anybody here makes more than $330
column9: 000 a year. I won't ask you
column10: but if you do
column11: you're in the top 1%.

column1: I'm not going to ask them. But if everyone here in this audience was dead on in the middle of the middle-class
column2: then the tax cuts for every single one of you all added up would be less than the tax cut his plan would give to just one member of that top wealthiest 1%. Now you judge for yourselves whether or not that's fair.

column1: Good. 50 million Americans get no tax relief under his plan.
That's not right.
You may not be one of them
column2: you're just not one of the right people. And secondly
column3: we've had enough fighting. It's time to unite. You talk about eight years? In eight years they haven't gotten anything done on Medicare
column4: on Social Security
column5: a patient's bill of rights. It's time to get something done.

column1: Hey
column2: I've got to answer that
column3: Jim.

column1: Medicare -- I cast the tie-breaking vote to add 26 years to the life of Medicare. It was due to go bankrupt in 1999 and that 50 million figure again
column2: the newspapers -- I said -- you said forget the journalists
column3: but they are the keepers of the score card and whether or not you're using facts that aren't right. And that fact is just not right.

column3: 5)	" What grade do you teach?

column1: High school. I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues. Traditionally
column2: if you've been involved in a campaign like that
column3: you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote. It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population
column4: but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever. More than 90% of America's children go to public schools. And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running. We've got to do something about this. And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts. They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it. Look
column5: we're in an information age. Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college. And again
column6: I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also
column7: and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning
column8: but it all starts with the public school teachers. My proposal gives $10
column9: 000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed. Now
column10: accountability
column11: we basically agree on accountability. My plan requires testing of all students. It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't. It requires testing of all new teachers
column12: including in the subjects that they teach. We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are
column13: and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.

column1: When you total up all the federal spending he wants to do
column2: it's the largest increase in federal spending in years. And there's just not going to be enough money. I have been a governor of a big state
column3: I have made education my number one priority. That's what governors ought to do. They ought to say this is the most important thing we do as a state. The federal government puts about 6% of the money up. They put about
column4: you know
column5: 60% of the strings where you have to fill out the paperwork. I don't know if you have to be a paperwork filler-outer
column6: but most of it's because of the federal government. What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money. One size does not fit all. I worry about federalizing education if I were you. I believe strongly that the federal government can help
column7: we need to fund Headstart. We need to have accountability. The Vice President's plan does not have annual accountability
column8: third grade
column9: fourth grade
column10: fifth grade. We need to demand on results. I believe strongly in a teacher protection act like I mentioned. I hear from teachers all the time about the lawsuits and the threats
column11: respect in the classroom. Part of it's because you can't -- you can't control the classroom. You can't have a consequence for somebody without fear of getting sued under federal law. So I'm going to ask the Congress to pass a teacher protection act. So I believe in flexibility
column12: I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing
column13: curriculum that works
column14: phonics works
column15: by the way
column16: it needs to be a part of our curriculum. There needs to be flexibility for teacher training and teacher hiring with federal money. The federal government can be a part
column17: but don't fall prey to all this stuff about money here and money there because education is really funded at the local level. 94% comes from the local level.

column1: Absolutely not. Absolutely not. I'm so glad that I have the chance to knock that down. Look
column2: the problem is that under Governor Bush's plan
column3: $1.6 trillion tax cut
column4: mostly to the wealthy
column5: under his own budget numbers
column6: he proposes spending more money for a tax cut just for the wealthiest 1% than all the new money he budgets for education
column7: health care and national defense combined. Now under my plan we'll balance the budget every year. I'm not just saying this. I'm not just talking. I have helped to balance the budget for the first time in 30 years
column8: paid down the debt. And under my plan
column9: in four years
column10: as the percentage of our gross domestic product
column11: federal spending will be the smallest that it has been in 50 years. One reason is
column12: you know
column13: the third biggest spending item in our budget is interest on the national debt? We get nothing for it. We keep the good faith and credit of the United States. I will pay down the debt every single year until it is eliminated early in the next decade. That gets rid of the third biggest intrusion of the federal government in our economy. Now
column14: because the governor has all this money for a tax cut mostly to the wealthy
column15: there is no money left over
column16: so schools get testing and lawsuit reform and not much else.

column1: Well
column2: he's wrong. (LAUGHTER) Just add up all the numbers. It's three times bigger than what President Clinton proposed. The Senate Budget Committee --

column1: That was in an ad
column2: Jim
column3: that was knocked down by the journalists who analyzed the ad and said it was misleading.

column1: My turn?
Forget the journalists. He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. This is a big spender. And he ought to be proud of it
column2: it's part of his record. We just have a different philosophy. Let me talk about tax relief. If you pay taxes
column3: you ought to get tax relief. The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I don't think that's the role of the president to pick you're right and you're not right. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody ought to get it. And therefore
column5: wealthy people are going to get it. But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits. And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes. If you're a family of four making $50
column6: 000 in Missouri
column7: you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes. What I've done is set priorities and funded them. And there's extra money. And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back. It's a difference of opinion. He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money. I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people. It's just the right position to take.

column1: Can we take the time --
Of course it does. If you pay taxes
column2: you are going to get a benefit. People who pay taxes will get tax relief.

column1: Let me finish. Under my plan
column2: if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today. Afterwards they pay 64%. This is a fair plan. You know why? Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother making $22
column3: 000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children
column4: for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200
column6: and that's not right. So I want to do something about that.

column1: Yeah
column2: look. Look
column3: this isn't about Governor Bush
column4: it's not about me. It is about you. And I want to come back to something I said before. If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then
column5: emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy
column6: here is your man. If you want somebody who will fight for you and who will fight to have middle-class tax cuts
column7: then I am your man. I want to be. Now
column8: I doubt anybody here makes more than $330
column9: 000 a year. I won't ask you
column10: but if you do
column11: you're in the top 1%.

column1: I'm not going to ask them. But if everyone here in this audience was dead on in the middle of the middle-class
column2: then the tax cuts for every single one of you all added up would be less than the tax cut his plan would give to just one member of that top wealthiest 1%. Now you judge for yourselves whether or not that's fair.

column1: Good. 50 million Americans get no tax relief under his plan.
That's not right.
You may not be one of them
column2: you're just not one of the right people. And secondly
column3: we've had enough fighting. It's time to unite. You talk about eight years? In eight years they haven't gotten anything done on Medicare
column4: on Social Security
column5: a patient's bill of rights. It's time to get something done.

column1: Hey
column2: I've got to answer that
column3: Jim.

column1: Medicare -- I cast the tie-breaking vote to add 26 years to the life of Medicare. It was due to go bankrupt in 1999 and that 50 million figure again
column2: the newspapers -- I said -- you said forget the journalists
column3: but they are the keepers of the score card and whether or not you're using facts that aren't right. And that fact is just not right.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 6)	" I've been a leader. I've been a person who has to set a clear vision and convince people to follow. I've got a strategy for the Middle East. And first let me say that our nation now needs to speak with one voice during this time
column4: and I applaud the president for working hard to diffuse tensions. Our nation needs to be credible and strong. When we say we're somebody's friend
column5: everybody has got to believe it. Israel is our friend and we'll stand by Israel. We need to reach out to moderate Arab nations as well to build coalitions to keep the peace. I also need -- the next leader needs to be patient. We can't put the Middle East peace process on our timetable. It's got to be on the timetable of the people that we're trying to bring to the peace table. We can't dictate the terms of peace
column6: which means that you have to be steady. You can't worry about polls or focus groups. You've got to have a clear vision. That's what a leader does. A leader also understands that the United States must be strong to keep the peace. Saddam Hussein still is a threat in the Middle East. Our coalition against Saddam is unraveling. Sanctions are loosened. The man who may be developing weapons of mass destruction
column7: we don't know because inspectors aren't in. So to answer your question
column8: it requires a clear vision
column9: a willingness to stand by our friends
column10: and the credibility for people both friend and foe to understand when America says something
column11: we mean it.

column1: I see a future when the world is at peace
column2: with the United States of America promoting the values of democracy and human rights and freedom all around the world. Even in Iran they have had an election that began to bring about some change. We stand for those values and we have to be willing to assert them. Right now our military is the strongest in the entire history of the world. I will -- I pledge to you I will do whatever is necessary to make sure that it stays that way. Now
column3: what can I bring to that challenge? When I was a young man
column4: my father was a senator opposed to the Vietnam War. When I graduated from college
column5: there were plenty of fancy ways to get out of going and being a part of that. I went and I volunteered
column6: and I went to Vietnam. I didn't do the most or run the greatest risk by a long shot
column7: but I learned what it was like to be an enlisted man in the United States Army. In the Congress
column8: in the House of Representatives
column9: I served on the House Intelligence Committee and I worked hard to learn the subject of nuclear arms control and how we can diffuse these tensions and deal with non-proliferation and deal with the problems of terrorism and these new weapons of mass destruction. Look
column10: we're gonna face some serious new challenges in the next four years. I've worked on that long and hard. When I went to the United States Senate
column11: I asked for an assignment to the Armed Services Committee. And while I was there I worked on a bipartisan basis
column12: as I did in the House
column13: I worked with former President Reagan on the modernization of our strategic weaponry. In the Senate I was one of only ten Democrats
column14: along with Senator Joe Lieberman
column15: to support Governor Bush's dad in the Persian Gulf War Resolution. And for the last eight years I've served on the National Security Council. Can I say just one other thing here?

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 7)	" Fine
column4: I'll wait.

column1: I think he gets a -- oh
column2: I'm sorry
column3: you're right
column4: go ahead.

column1: Thank you
column2: sir. Just to finish briefly
column3: I started to say that for the last eight years I've been on the National Security Council. Last week I broke up -- I suspended campaigning for two days
column4: or parts of two days
column5: to go back and participate in the meetings that charted the President's summit meeting that he just returned from earlier today. And our team of -- our country's team over there did a great job. It's a difficult situation. The United States has to be strong in order to make sure that we can help promote peace and security and stability. And that means keeping our military strong. Now
column6: I said earlier that we are the strongest military
column7: but we need to continue improving readiness and making sure that our military personnel are adequately paid and that the combination of their pay and their benefits and their retirement as veterans is comparable to the stiff competition that's coming in this strong economy from the private sector. And I have supported the largest pay raise in many a year
column8: and I support another one now. I also support modernization of our strategic and tactical weaponry. The governor has proposed skipping a generation of technology. I think that would be a mistake
column9: because I think one of the ways we've been able to be so successful in Kosovo and Bosnia and Haiti and in other places is by having the technological edge. You know
column10: we won that conflict in Kosovo without losing a single human life in combat
column11: a single American life in combat. Now
column12: readiness. The trends before we -- before I got my current job were on the decline
column13: the number of divisions were reduced. I argued that we should reverse that trend and take it back up. And I'm happy to tell you that we have. Now
column14: in my budget for the next ten years I propose $100 billion for this purpose. The governor proposes $45 billion. I propose more than twice as much because I think it's needed.

column1: If this were a spending contest
column2: I would come in second. I readily admit I'm not going to grow the size of the federal government like he is. Your question was deployment. It must be in the national interests
column3: must be in our vital interests whether we ever send troops. The mission must be clear. Soldiers must understand why we're going. The force must be strong enough so that the mission can be accomplished. And the exit strategy needs to be well-defined. I'm concerned that we're overdeployed around the world. See
column4: I think the mission has somewhat become fuzzy. Should I be fortunate enough to earn your confidence
column5: the mission of the United States military will be to be prepared and ready to fight and win war. And therefore prevent war from happening in the first place. There may be some moments when we use our troops as peacekeepers
column6: but not often. The Vice President mentioned my view of long-term for the military. I want to make sure the equipment for our military is the best it can possibly be
column7: of course. But we have an opportunity -- we have an opportunity to use our research and development capacities
column8: the great technology of the United States
column9: to make our military lighter
column10: harder to find
column11: more lethal. We have an opportunity
column12: really
column13: if you think about it
column14: if we're smart and have got a strategic vision and a leader who understands strategic planning
column15: to make sure that we change the terms of the battlefield of the future so we can keep the peace. This is a peaceful nation
column16: and I intend to keep the peace. Spending money is one thing. But spending money without a strategic plan can oftentimes be wasted. First thing I'm going to do is ask the Secretary of Defense to develop a plan so we are making sure we're not spending our money on political projects
column17: but on projects to make sure our soldiers are well-paid
column18: well-housed
column19: and have the best equipment in the world.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 8)	" Yes
column4: sir.

column1: I'm sorry
column2: I didn't hear that.

column1: I don't think the National Rifle Association ran that ad. But let me just tell you my position on guns in general
column2: sir
column3: if you don't mind.

column1: I'm sorry.
Well
column2: I don't think I ran the ad. I think somebody who doesn't want me to be president might have run that ad. That wasn't my ad. I think it might have been one of my opponent's ads. Here is what I believe
column3: sir. I believe law-abiding citizens ought to be allowed to protect themselves and their families. I believe that we ought to keep guns out of the hands of people that shouldn't have them. That's why I'm for instant background checks at gun shows
column4: I'm for trigger locks
column5: I think that makes sense. Matter of fact
column6: we distributed free trigger locks in the State of Texas so that people can get them and put them on their guns to make their guns more safe. I think we ought to raise the age at which juveniles can have a gun. But I also believe strongly that we need to enforce laws on the books that the best way to make sure that we keep our society safe and secure is to hold people accountable for breaking the law. If we catch somebody illegally selling a gun
column7: there needs to be a consequence. If we keep somebody -- you know
column8: illegally using a gun
column9: there needs to be a consequence. Enforcement of law
column10: and the federal government can help. There is a great program called Project Exile in Richmond
column11: Virginia
column12: where we focused federal taxpayers' money and federal prosecutors and went after people who were illegally using guns. To me that's how you make society the safest it can be. And so
column13: yeah
column14: sometimes I agree with some of these groups in Washington and sometimes I don't. I'm a pretty independent thinker. The one thing I'm for is a safe society. And I'm for enforcing laws on the books. And that's what is going to happen should I earn your confidence.

column1: Well
column2: it was not one of my ads
column3: either
column4: Governor. But I am familiar with the statement
column5: and it was made by one of the top-ranking officials of that organization. Let me tell you my position. I think that some common sense gun safety measures are certainly needed with the flood of cheap handguns that have sometimes been working their way into the hands of the wrong people. But all of my proposals are focused on that problem
column6: gun safety. None of my proposals would have any effect on hunters
column7: or sportsmen
column8: or people who use rifles. They're aimed at the real problem. Let's make our schools safe
column9: let's make our neighborhoods safe. Let's have a three-day waiting period
column10: cooling off
column11: so we can have a background check to make sure that criminals and people who really shouldn't have guns don't get them. But I would like to use my remaining time on this exchange
column12: Jim
column13: to respond to an exchange that took place just a moment ago. Because a couple of times the governor has said that I am for a bigger government. Governor
column14: I'm not. And let me tell you what the record shows. For the last eight years I have had the challenge of running the streamlining program called Reinventing Government. And if there are any federal employees in this group
column15: you know what that means. The federal government has been reduced in size by more than 300
column16: 000 people. And it's now the smallest number that we have had since the -- the smallest in size since John Kennedy's administration. During the last five years
column17: Texas's government has gone up in size. Federal government has gone down
column18: Texas's government has gone up. Now
column19: my plan for the future
column20: I see a time when we have smaller
column21: smarter government where you don't have to wait in line because you can get services online cheaper
column23: faster. We can do that.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 9)	" We've got a bumper crop this year. But that's the good news. You know what the bad news is that follows on that. The prices are low. In the last several years
column4: the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has
column5: in my view
column6: been mostly a failure. I want to change many of its provisions. Now
column7: many here who are not involved in farming don't -- won't follow this
column8: so just forgive me. Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them. And you guys have been having a hard time
column9: and I want to fight for you. I want to change those provisions. I want to restore a meaningful safety net. And I think that you pointed the way in your comments
column10: because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers
column11: you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment. And yes
column12: farmers are the first environmentalists. And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion
column13: that may cost them a little money
column14: but it helps the environment. I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program. And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation
column15: and when you leave the land fallow and the rest. Now
column16: I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs. I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy. So we need to do a lot of things
column17: but we ought to start with a better safety net.

column1: I would like our farmers feeding the world. We're the best producers in the world
column2: and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world. We need to open up markets. Exports are down
column3: and every time an export number goes down
column4: it hurts the farmer. I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world. Weâ€™re the best and the most efficient farmers. I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward. We shouldn't be using food. It hurts the farmers. It's not the right thing to do. I'm for value-added processing. We need more work on value-added processing. You take the raw product you produce
column5: I presume you're a farmer
column6: off your farm
column7: and you convert it. Value-added processing is important. I'm for research and development. Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products. I'm for getting rid of the death tax
column8: completely getting rid of the death tax. One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax. This is a bad tax. The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill. It's a tax that taxes people twice. It penalizes the family farmer. So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote
column9: I also understand -- I want to open up markets
column10: but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security. I'm from a big farm state. We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country. And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time. The Vice President is right
column11: by the way. Every day is earth day if you own the land. I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes. Thank you.

column1: Yeah. I'm for a massive reform of the estate tax or the death tax. And under the plan that I've proposed
column2: 80% of all family farms will be completely exempt from the estate tax. And the vast majority of all family businesses would be completely exempt
column3: and all of the others would have sharply reduced. So 80% -- now the problem with completely eliminating it goes back to the wealthiest 1%. The amount of money that has to be raised in taxes for middle-class families to make up for completely eliminating that on the very wealthiest
column4: the billionaires
column5: that would be an extra heavy burden on middle-class families. And so let's do it for most all
column6: but not completely eliminate it for the very top.

column1: Eliminating the death tax.
Because people shouldn't be taxed twice on their assets. It's either unfair for some or unfair for all. Again
column2: this is just a difference of opinion. If you're from Washington
column3: you want to pick and choose winners. I don't think that's the role of the president. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody benefits. Secondly
column5: I think your plan -- a lot of fine print in your plan
column6: Mr. Vice President
column7: with all due respect. It is -- I'm not so sure 80% of the people get the death tax. I know this
column8: 100% will get it if I'm the president. I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status. It's a fairness issue. It's an issue of principle
column9: not politics.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 9)	" We've got a bumper crop this year. But that's the good news. You know what the bad news is that follows on that. The prices are low. In the last several years
column4: the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has
column5: in my view
column6: been mostly a failure. I want to change many of its provisions. Now
column7: many here who are not involved in farming don't -- won't follow this
column8: so just forgive me. Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them. And you guys have been having a hard time
column9: and I want to fight for you. I want to change those provisions. I want to restore a meaningful safety net. And I think that you pointed the way in your comments
column10: because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers
column11: you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment. And yes
column12: farmers are the first environmentalists. And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion
column13: that may cost them a little money
column14: but it helps the environment. I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program. And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation
column15: and when you leave the land fallow and the rest. Now
column16: I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs. I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy. So we need to do a lot of things
column17: but we ought to start with a better safety net.

column1: I would like our farmers feeding the world. We're the best producers in the world
column2: and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world. We need to open up markets. Exports are down
column3: and every time an export number goes down
column4: it hurts the farmer. I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world. Weâ€™re the best and the most efficient farmers. I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward. We shouldn't be using food. It hurts the farmers. It's not the right thing to do. I'm for value-added processing. We need more work on value-added processing. You take the raw product you produce
column5: I presume you're a farmer
column6: off your farm
column7: and you convert it. Value-added processing is important. I'm for research and development. Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products. I'm for getting rid of the death tax
column8: completely getting rid of the death tax. One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax. This is a bad tax. The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill. It's a tax that taxes people twice. It penalizes the family farmer. So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote
column9: I also understand -- I want to open up markets
column10: but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security. I'm from a big farm state. We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country. And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time. The Vice President is right
column11: by the way. Every day is earth day if you own the land. I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes. Thank you.

column1: Yeah. I'm for a massive reform of the estate tax or the death tax. And under the plan that I've proposed
column2: 80% of all family farms will be completely exempt from the estate tax. And the vast majority of all family businesses would be completely exempt
column3: and all of the others would have sharply reduced. So 80% -- now the problem with completely eliminating it goes back to the wealthiest 1%. The amount of money that has to be raised in taxes for middle-class families to make up for completely eliminating that on the very wealthiest
column4: the billionaires
column5: that would be an extra heavy burden on middle-class families. And so let's do it for most all
column6: but not completely eliminate it for the very top.

column1: Eliminating the death tax.
Because people shouldn't be taxed twice on their assets. It's either unfair for some or unfair for all. Again
column2: this is just a difference of opinion. If you're from Washington
column3: you want to pick and choose winners. I don't think that's the role of the president. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody benefits. Secondly
column5: I think your plan -- a lot of fine print in your plan
column6: Mr. Vice President
column7: with all due respect. It is -- I'm not so sure 80% of the people get the death tax. I know this
column8: 100% will get it if I'm the president. I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status. It's a fairness issue. It's an issue of principle
column9: not politics.

column3: 9)	" We've got a bumper crop this year. But that's the good news. You know what the bad news is that follows on that. The prices are low. In the last several years
column4: the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has
column5: in my view
column6: been mostly a failure. I want to change many of its provisions. Now
column7: many here who are not involved in farming don't -- won't follow this
column8: so just forgive me. Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them. And you guys have been having a hard time
column9: and I want to fight for you. I want to change those provisions. I want to restore a meaningful safety net. And I think that you pointed the way in your comments
column10: because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers
column11: you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment. And yes
column12: farmers are the first environmentalists. And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion
column13: that may cost them a little money
column14: but it helps the environment. I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program. And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation
column15: and when you leave the land fallow and the rest. Now
column16: I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs. I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy. So we need to do a lot of things
column17: but we ought to start with a better safety net.

column1: I would like our farmers feeding the world. We're the best producers in the world
column2: and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world. We need to open up markets. Exports are down
column3: and every time an export number goes down
column4: it hurts the farmer. I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world. Weâ€™re the best and the most efficient farmers. I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward. We shouldn't be using food. It hurts the farmers. It's not the right thing to do. I'm for value-added processing. We need more work on value-added processing. You take the raw product you produce
column5: I presume you're a farmer
column6: off your farm
column7: and you convert it. Value-added processing is important. I'm for research and development. Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products. I'm for getting rid of the death tax
column8: completely getting rid of the death tax. One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax. This is a bad tax. The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill. It's a tax that taxes people twice. It penalizes the family farmer. So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote
column9: I also understand -- I want to open up markets
column10: but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security. I'm from a big farm state. We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country. And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time. The Vice President is right
column11: by the way. Every day is earth day if you own the land. I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes. Thank you.

column6: but not completely eliminate it for the very top.

column6: Mr. Vice President

column8: 100% will get it if I'm the president. I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status. It's a fairness issue. It's an issue of principle

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 9)	" We've got a bumper crop this year. But that's the good news. You know what the bad news is that follows on that. The prices are low. In the last several years
column4: the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has
column5: in my view
column6: been mostly a failure. I want to change many of its provisions. Now
column7: many here who are not involved in farming don't -- won't follow this
column8: so just forgive me. Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them. And you guys have been having a hard time
column9: and I want to fight for you. I want to change those provisions. I want to restore a meaningful safety net. And I think that you pointed the way in your comments
column10: because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers
column11: you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment. And yes
column12: farmers are the first environmentalists. And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion
column13: that may cost them a little money
column14: but it helps the environment. I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program. And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation
column15: and when you leave the land fallow and the rest. Now
column16: I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs. I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy. So we need to do a lot of things
column17: but we ought to start with a better safety net.

column1: I would like our farmers feeding the world. We're the best producers in the world
column2: and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world. We need to open up markets. Exports are down
column3: and every time an export number goes down
column4: it hurts the farmer. I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world. Weâ€™re the best and the most efficient farmers. I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward. We shouldn't be using food. It hurts the farmers. It's not the right thing to do. I'm for value-added processing. We need more work on value-added processing. You take the raw product you produce
column5: I presume you're a farmer
column6: off your farm
column7: and you convert it. Value-added processing is important. I'm for research and development. Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products. I'm for getting rid of the death tax
column8: completely getting rid of the death tax. One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax. This is a bad tax. The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill. It's a tax that taxes people twice. It penalizes the family farmer. So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote
column9: I also understand -- I want to open up markets
column10: but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security. I'm from a big farm state. We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country. And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time. The Vice President is right
column11: by the way. Every day is earth day if you own the land. I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes. Thank you.

column1: Yeah. I'm for a massive reform of the estate tax or the death tax. And under the plan that I've proposed
column2: 80% of all family farms will be completely exempt from the estate tax. And the vast majority of all family businesses would be completely exempt
column3: and all of the others would have sharply reduced. So 80% -- now the problem with completely eliminating it goes back to the wealthiest 1%. The amount of money that has to be raised in taxes for middle-class families to make up for completely eliminating that on the very wealthiest
column4: the billionaires
column5: that would be an extra heavy burden on middle-class families. And so let's do it for most all
column6: but not completely eliminate it for the very top.

column1: Eliminating the death tax.
Because people shouldn't be taxed twice on their assets. It's either unfair for some or unfair for all. Again
column2: this is just a difference of opinion. If you're from Washington
column3: you want to pick and choose winners. I don't think that's the role of the president. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody benefits. Secondly
column5: I think your plan -- a lot of fine print in your plan
column6: Mr. Vice President
column7: with all due respect. It is -- I'm not so sure 80% of the people get the death tax. I know this
column8: 100% will get it if I'm the president. I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status. It's a fairness issue. It's an issue of principle
column9: not politics.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 9)	" We've got a bumper crop this year. But that's the good news. You know what the bad news is that follows on that. The prices are low. In the last several years
column4: the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has
column5: in my view
column6: been mostly a failure. I want to change many of its provisions. Now
column7: many here who are not involved in farming don't -- won't follow this
column8: so just forgive me. Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them. And you guys have been having a hard time
column9: and I want to fight for you. I want to change those provisions. I want to restore a meaningful safety net. And I think that you pointed the way in your comments
column10: because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers
column11: you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment. And yes
column12: farmers are the first environmentalists. And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion
column13: that may cost them a little money
column14: but it helps the environment. I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program. And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation
column15: and when you leave the land fallow and the rest. Now
column16: I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs. I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy. So we need to do a lot of things
column17: but we ought to start with a better safety net.

column1: I would like our farmers feeding the world. We're the best producers in the world
column2: and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world. We need to open up markets. Exports are down
column3: and every time an export number goes down
column4: it hurts the farmer. I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world. Weâ€™re the best and the most efficient farmers. I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward. We shouldn't be using food. It hurts the farmers. It's not the right thing to do. I'm for value-added processing. We need more work on value-added processing. You take the raw product you produce
column5: I presume you're a farmer
column6: off your farm
column7: and you convert it. Value-added processing is important. I'm for research and development. Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products. I'm for getting rid of the death tax
column8: completely getting rid of the death tax. One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax. This is a bad tax. The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill. It's a tax that taxes people twice. It penalizes the family farmer. So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote
column9: I also understand -- I want to open up markets
column10: but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security. I'm from a big farm state. We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country. And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time. The Vice President is right
column11: by the way. Every day is earth day if you own the land. I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes. Thank you.

column1: Yeah. I'm for a massive reform of the estate tax or the death tax. And under the plan that I've proposed
column2: 80% of all family farms will be completely exempt from the estate tax. And the vast majority of all family businesses would be completely exempt
column3: and all of the others would have sharply reduced. So 80% -- now the problem with completely eliminating it goes back to the wealthiest 1%. The amount of money that has to be raised in taxes for middle-class families to make up for completely eliminating that on the very wealthiest
column4: the billionaires
column5: that would be an extra heavy burden on middle-class families. And so let's do it for most all
column6: but not completely eliminate it for the very top.

column1: Eliminating the death tax.
Because people shouldn't be taxed twice on their assets. It's either unfair for some or unfair for all. Again
column2: this is just a difference of opinion. If you're from Washington
column3: you want to pick and choose winners. I don't think that's the role of the president. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody benefits. Secondly
column5: I think your plan -- a lot of fine print in your plan
column6: Mr. Vice President
column7: with all due respect. It is -- I'm not so sure 80% of the people get the death tax. I know this
column8: 100% will get it if I'm the president. I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status. It's a fairness issue. It's an issue of principle
column9: not politics.

column2: '17Oct'
column3: 9)	" We've got a bumper crop this year. But that's the good news. You know what the bad news is that follows on that. The prices are low. In the last several years
column4: the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has
column5: in my view
column6: been mostly a failure. I want to change many of its provisions. Now
column7: many here who are not involved in farming don't -- won't follow this
column8: so just forgive me. Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them. And you guys have been having a hard time
column9: and I want to fight for you. I want to change those provisions. I want to restore a meaningful safety net. And I think that you pointed the way in your comments
column10: because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers
column11: you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment. And yes
column12: farmers are the first environmentalists. And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion
column13: that may cost them a little money
column14: but it helps the environment. I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program. And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation
column15: and when you leave the land fallow and the rest. Now
column16: I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs. I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy. So we need to do a lot of things
column17: but we ought to start with a better safety net.

column1: I would like our farmers feeding the world. We're the best producers in the world
column2: and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world. We need to open up markets. Exports are down
column3: and every time an export number goes down
column4: it hurts the farmer. I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world. Weâ€™re the best and the most efficient farmers. I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward. We shouldn't be using food. It hurts the farmers. It's not the right thing to do. I'm for value-added processing. We need more work on value-added processing. You take the raw product you produce
column5: I presume you're a farmer
column6: off your farm
column7: and you convert it. Value-added processing is important. I'm for research and development. Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products. I'm for getting rid of the death tax
column8: completely getting rid of the death tax. One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax. This is a bad tax. The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill. It's a tax that taxes people twice. It penalizes the family farmer. So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote
column9: I also understand -- I want to open up markets
column10: but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security. I'm from a big farm state. We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country. And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time. The Vice President is right
column11: by the way. Every day is earth day if you own the land. I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes. Thank you.

column1: Yeah. I'm for a massive reform of the estate tax or the death tax. And under the plan that I've proposed
column2: 80% of all family farms will be completely exempt from the estate tax. And the vast majority of all family businesses would be completely exempt
column3: and all of the others would have sharply reduced. So 80% -- now the problem with completely eliminating it goes back to the wealthiest 1%. The amount of money that has to be raised in taxes for middle-class families to make up for completely eliminating that on the very wealthiest
column4: the billionaires
column5: that would be an extra heavy burden on middle-class families. And so let's do it for most all
column6: but not completely eliminate it for the very top.

column1: Eliminating the death tax.
Because people shouldn't be taxed twice on their assets. It's either unfair for some or unfair for all. Again
column2: this is just a difference of opinion. If you're from Washington
column3: you want to pick and choose winners. I don't think that's the role of the president. I think if you're going to have tax relief
column4: everybody benefits. Secondly
column5: I think your plan -- a lot of fine print in your plan
column6: Mr. Vice President
column7: with all due respect. It is -- I'm not so sure 80% of the people get the death tax. I know this
column8: 100% will get it if I'm the president. I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status. It's a fairness issue. It's an issue of principle
column9: not politics.
